reviewText:
Early Access Review

Written as of Release 1.947, 19 April, 2016.

This game is one I've been addicted to for months now. I may not have the hours to show it, as I play a fair amount offline, but the experience is definitely here. I'll have a quick summary. Would I recommend From The Depths to someone who is willing to learn and values gaining experience through trial and error? Yes. Would I recommend it to someone who just wants a simple game that's easy to get into and you can easily become a powerful god in? Absolutely not.

Well, why would I recommend this to the first type of people? Well, it's a hard game. I'm not going to lie. This game will slam your face in the ground many times. But the ones who learn from things like that will thrive off of what they learned from that. They'll get back up, dust themselves off, and fix the problem before heading back in. A fair amount of knowledge is useful in From The Depths. Simple physics, some mathematics, advanced problem solving, etc. But even people who don't know those can easily excel with the will to learn from mistakes. Your ship keeps flipping over? Well, time to make sure the center of mass sits lower in the vehicle. Basic problem solving can soothe the rage I see in others.

But what about the second group, Dim? As I said, it's a hard game. Not everything will just pop right up to you. I first started playing this before the new tutorial additions, and let me tell you, it was hard. 90% of what I know came from reverse engineering, experimentation, and watching others. But now there's a much better tutorial system that even helped me with some things. I can say if you instantly want to be a god at building things, this will never be the game for you. No amount of tutorials will ever make it so. You have to be able to not get frustrated at every little thing and be able to problem solve. It takes time.

Now some people complain about the horrible" UI. Well
recommended: it's extremely simple and definitely not pretty. But it gets the job done. There are a few things that I'd say are difficult to figure out
hoursPlayed: but once you get it
voteText: it's second nature. I will admittedly say the multiplayer is lackluster. It's originally what I got the game for
helpfulPercent: to play with friends. But now they're working on it. It's an Early Access game after all. There will be issues. There are quite a few other little issues
votesHelpful: but everything is subject to change since I first typed this. No game is perfect. I will say the learning curve was rough
votesTotal:
but the game must have some addictive drug in it after you get the hang of what to do.

Pros:
Amazing building capabilities
Smart AI systems (usually)
Infinite combinations of gun systems
Highly reactive physics
Superb combat effects (shell impacts
votesFunny: pieces flying off
commentsCount:
etc.)
Amazingly rewarding for the ones who persist
Great graphics (for a Voxel game)

Cons:
Harsh learning curve
Poor optimization
Poor multiplayer
Small glitches (shouldn't be much of a problem
column16:
however)

Overall:
8/10. Amazing game in my opinion
column17: but it has flaws. Worth the buy for those willing to invest some time into it."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do not be scared by the early access tag, the game is already easily  worth the price tag, and the developer is very active. This is an gem of a game. The building is fluid, and the amount of creations you can make are endless. Be it a barn, battleship, or a battle-balloon you can build it in this game.

Construction is fluid (sim planes, tool bars, ect all ease building tremendously)

Customization is endless, your not just designing the chassis or the guns here. Everything from the cannon barrels, to the hull, to the props is of your creation. There's even an editor if you tire of the stock campaign.

The campaign is a unique feature all on its own. The ships you build in designer can be spawned in campaign for use there, where the game plays somewhat like an RTS.

If your looking at buying this game, just take a moment to view the workshop. Alternativly you can join the TS3 channel IP: 85.236.105.19:11407 Password thisisgonnabeawesome

DISCLAIMER: While this is a voxel game, the learning curve is very steep. Although new tutorial are being made, I would STRONGLY suggest taking a look at the forums here: http://www.fromthedepthsgame.com/forum/index.php
voteText: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've watched hours of videos on how to play this game before I bought it so don't let the hours I have in it at the moment deceive you. So far this is the best game I've played in years, Honestly my entire life I've looked for a game with such an easily customizable AI system that's still super in-depth as this one.

Don't get me wrong, however. This game is NOT easy. The controls aren't easy, the mechanics aren't easy, and even the battles aren't easy. This game is more than just a challenge for your reaction skills though. This game is a challenge for your brain. Coming up with new and innovative ways to use the mechanics to make amazing creations for either looks or potency is what is, has, and will always be what separates this game from the others. This game is Minecraft on steroids. If you enjoy being able to build legos with computers that you can program to do pretty much whatever you want, then this game is for you. I would highly recommend even though there is one glaring issue I will address down below.

I'll cut the developer some slack and let any bugs slide for now since it is after all an alpha. The one thing I do have slight issue with however is the framerate. My pc is more than capable of running most games and in smaller engagements I lose slim to no fps. However in the larger battles and even the benchmark it goes and stays around 10-12 fps on the lowest settings. I sincerely hope the dev will have some sort of breakthrough in the code to get more performance out of the larger battles because that's the only thorn in the side of this game right now.

Other than that, I would recommend this to only the more intelligent of my friends. Not to insult anyone's intelligence but unless you're smarter than the average gamer, this game will get on your nerves quickly with all of the mechanics it has available. It can easily overwhelm a newbie or a more casual gamer so take caution, this game is not for the faint of mind.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A block building game that feels nothing like Minecraft or any of its clones. You build ships, planes, submarines, or whatever else you can imagine, arm them like they are a SWAT team of Jayne Cobbs and let them free. If you want to go truly crazy you could make enough explosions that even Michael Bay would say it was a bit excessive. Would recommend to anyone who played with legos and always ended up building battlecruisers and dreadnaughts.

Only feels like a (pre)alpha in the multiplayer, which is still very buggy, but its new and being improved.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I didn't know i wanted this game, until i got it. From The Depths is a game about both creativity and efficiency. In order to vanquish your enemies you must build up an automated army of ships and flying vehicles that can fufill it's job as efficiantly as possible. making a wodden boat with a big cannon on the front you let you get by... for a little while, but eventually your opponents will start making truly fearsome vessels, at wich point you must start thinking outside the box and approach things in different ways.
I could spend litteraly days in the vehicle designer, testing designs, optimising older ones and then pitting them against enemies to see how they perform, so that i can see what i did well and what needs improving.
The concept of FTD is what makes this a worthy investment, but you may want to purchase it later on. As is the way of early access games, there are things that are planned, but not in the game yet. Indeed there are quite a few missing features as of writing. There are also performance problems, mainly when huge battles take place, the game can slow to a crawl.
The way I see it, if you're gonna buy one early access game, this is a great choise. I guarantee, if you like the sound of the concept alone, then you will find it worth your time. I wholehartedly reccommend this one.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As you can see, I have a good amount of time spent in this game. It's not every day that you can get that many hours of entertainment for the price of a large pizza. It's not even finished yet, and there is already plenty to enjoy.

PROS:
Extremely impressive for an alpha build, despite having a very small dev team.
Very good community interaction.
Virtually all aspects of the game under constant improvement.
Already has a functional single player campaign and skirmish missions, dedicated build mode, and multiplayer cooperative construction.
Mod support being implemented.
Multiple custom campaigns made by the community.
World creation with customizable gravity, air density, water buoyancy, space altitude, etc.
All built-in vehicles and structures can be examined in build mode to see how they work.
Active forum community willing and able to answer questions and help players.
Developers active on forums.

CONS:
Not a finished game yet.
Performance slowdowns in some situations.
Many game systems still being adjusted, not fully balanced yet.
Learning curve can be steep for beginners.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

About:
This game is a sandbox based around water and Aerial fights. Just for being in Pre-Alpha there is an insane amount of content in this, one of my favorite aspects is the custonizable weapons, (custom cannons and missiles). All you can do in this game so far is a few story missions and a campaign where you conquer the map while building better and better ships along the way. Infact, you dont have to build each ship block by block, you can make ships in the editor and save them, then make them in the campaign so long as you have resources for it.

Creativity:
This game relies heavily on your own creativity. The better you can imagine something, the better you can make it in-game. Not trying to turn people away here, because there is the workshop where you can look for inspiration for your own creations.

Difficulty:
This game can be very challenging when you first start as you can not just build a little raft with a cannon twice the size of the raft and expect it to float (it will sink like a rock, trust me i tried).
once you get where you can build the bigger and better stuff later in campaign the bigger and better your ships can/have to be as the AI has better and better ships as you progress.

Performance:
I run an okay rig with about 6GB of ram and this game runs nicely, so long as you dont have anything open in the background. With me only having 6GB of RAM it takes almost all when you get into a battle with ships that fire ~4 shells a second. Other than that one small problem It runs nicely.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(This is an Early Access game, review written on 4/8/16)

From the Depths is an engineering game where you construct naval ships, aircraft, subs, and structures to shoot at and conquer other ships, aircraft, subs, and structures.  This is done mostly in first-person although there are map overview RTS aspects as well.

From the Depths has a lot of, well, depth to its building.  Every aspect of your air/water craft is constructed of essentially minecraft blocks.  Even fuctional aspects, like the engines or weaponry, are contructed of special blocks.  There are several weapon types to build, including two types of naval cannon, missiles and torpedoes, and even lasers, each with relative checks and balances.  There is a ton of customization when it comes to building your fleet, but there is also a big learning curve.  I feel this curve is not insurmountable though.

There is a strategic campaign where you fight and defeat 8 unique factions for world domination or something.  The forces featured are largely designed by the community.  The campaign can be fairly challenging for a newer player, but it can get very unbalanced later on, as you get an over abundance of resources.

While Early Access titles are typically very dubious in value, I find From the Depths trustworthy.  The dev is fairly active on the official forums, and often informs us on what he is working on.  I've owned this game for about six months, and multiple major updates with big features have been released.

Overall, From the Depths is a complex but nonetheless fun and intriguing game in the build-stuff-out-of-blocks genre.
voteText: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Out of all the vehicle building games around I played a lot of (Space Engineers, Empyirion Galactic Survival, Starmade) I have to say, this one is my favorite.

You can do so much!
At the time I wrote this review, you could do: Ships, Hydrofoils, Hovercrafts(Well, technically. But there's no hovercraft skirt parts right now, just thrusters and propellers), Submarines(those are a bit trickier to get working AI wise), Aircrafts, Airships, Spacecrafts, Helicopters(Those are tricky to make too), and they just added land vehicles(Still rough around the edges, and not very usable in combat, but some fun can be had with those already).
Or, you can get creative and just abuse the physic engine to make weird contraptions :B

The game relies mainly on AI to control the vehicles/structures you build in the game. The AI is still a bit wonky, especially path finding and collision avoidance, but its possible to minimize the problems using long range weapons and spreading your ships around in formations. However, it'll always find a way to use whatever you give it..
Another nice thing is that, your creation can be controlled in battle using a strategic map view, which makes things much easier.

Manual controls are available, but, right now they're very limited, convoluted, and not very practical for anything that's more than a simple basic ship. And even then, there's some weirdness with it. However, I'm pretty sure the devs are definitely going to fix those in a way or another before release.

The build mode is probably one of my favorite part of this game. I'm talking about Keyboard mode. Its really efficient and handy most of the time. Most people seems to say it has a high learning curve, but personally I figure it out under 2 hours, after watching the video tutorial. And I usually have issues with different control schemes in games. (Actually, the vehicle steering controls are more confusing than this tbh)
Sure its a bit intimidating at first, but try messing around with it, not building anything serious. Your first ship will probably be a complete piece of junk that keeps sinking on its own, or capsizing but try watching getting started tutorial videos by Irelan gaming for example, you'll understand a lot better how to make things work. Or you can also just spawn ships/vehicles from the campaign and take them apart and see how they managed to make them float/fly/etc and work.

One thing I love particularly here is the way you can customize almost every system you build with attachements and extensions. Nearly all systems are multi-blocks. And not just in a quantitative way, like Starmade for example(AKA more blocks == more powerful) Building large systems without powerful enough support systems to back them up will yield a pretty innefective system. It'll still work, but you could do better use of your space.
For instance, you can build a huge engine, but it'll drink so much fuel at mid and low RPMs compared to several smaller engines that turn on and off to meet demands that you'll get a very fuel hungry design with a very weak spot. And well, there's also overheating to take into account, but its pretty manageable, even though radiators are pretty shoddy right now.
Of course, you can do that with way more things than just engines! Weapons systems, propellers, etc.. And probably more in the future. You can build canons from the magazine to the tip of the barrels. You assemble each parts together to get the best out of the space you have, while making sure a single shell won't find a way to hit your magazines and blow everything up! And you can customize your shells, build gauss canons, add timed/proximity detonation and a lot more!

The recent weapon and armor rebalance did a pretty solid job at balancing out the game. AKA you can't sink a big floating metal castle ship armored with 2 to 5m of armor, with an army of tiny ships with 20mm chainloaded AP guns anymore :P
Some things are still a bit overpowered though, and some things definitely need some work. Namely UI, engine and power mechanics, shields, player weapons, land vehicles, space vehicles and the physics involved with going to space.

But, from what the devs teased, there's a lot of great improvements coming soon. And even in this state, the game is a ton of fun. Playing the campaign and designing your ships, or refitting any enemy ships you manage to capture, sending massive fleets against an enemy's forces is already tons of fun IMO.

The devs are overall doing amazing work with this game! They listen to feedback, keeps asking questions and mentioning what they're working on in the forums, and release patches and content regularly. (During early access at least)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, where to start.

This is a brilliant little Indie game!  Extremely tactical and strategic on a grand scale.

It is really satisfying spending hours creating the perfect Submarine/Ship/Airplane/Spaceship and then either controlling it yourself or watching it dominate the competition or fail miserably because of a weakness that you overlooked :)

Incoming Features planned by Nick Smart, the head dev:

Coop Campaign and coop in general!

Even more costomisable weapons, like Rail Cannons!

Even more simple non-customisable weapons!

Nuclear Reactors!

Many more listed here:
http://www.fromthedepthsgame.com/forum/index.php

Things already included in the game and which I enjoy very much..some of these are still work in progress and are marked clearly ingame as such.  The things listed below though are functional and enjoyable :)

Customisable engines...electric and diesel!

Resource gathering

Character Development (Stats, Items, Self Buffs, Fleet Buffs)

Customisable Cannons, Lasers, Missiles, Torpedos, Ships, Aircraft, Submarines, Spaceships, Ballons and Blimps!

Proper physics...build your boat fully out of metal..its gonna sink!  Lose an important chunk of your aircraft during a fight, it will drop like a stone!  Unless of course your creation is a homing Kamikaze flying bomb, then you want it to do that!

Anyway, so sum it all up, if you like creating, destroying, imagining or copying, this is your game!

I hope you enjoy this gem of a game as much as I do.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game:

Build your own units block by block, customize their weapons, create fleets, romp around the map and kill other custom ships. Cannons, lasers, missiles, mines, torpedoes, missiles that turn into torpedos or mines, big warheads, small warheads, lots of warheads, guided, shrapnel, unguided...

Have fun watching your custom build ship or jet or spaceship or sattelite or weird ballon-laser-missile battery munch through their targets, weep as you recognize critical flaws in your desings as they crumble and get destroyed. Watch your first iron hulled ship drop right down to the ocean floor, be happy when your first iron hulled jet-rockethelicopter thing takes to the skies, immediately fails to shoot someone but still wins because it hit and killed the enemy when it crashed down to earth after getting shot....



From the depths is great fun, its a strategy game where you build your own units, block by block and then conquer the map with them. Look at the workshop to see what we predictable lot have already build.

Game state:
No severe crashbugs or gamebreaking gamebugs in the gameworld have been observed by me in my time of playing, which began at around mid september.
I rate the game as stable and the gamepaly is already functional (construct your ships, build them  in campaign, wipe the map clean of filth colored differently than you.).

Dev:
The Developer has no negative trackrecord to my knowledge, the game is getting updates.
Dev is active in both the steam forum as well as his own.


I sincerely recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Absolutley flawless, and its even still in early access with this level of polish! A solid game here even in this stage of development, fun mechanics, easy to learn design system, resource based consructions and real time damage on a block by block basis. Careful and clever design is key to making a solid ship/sub/plane/spaceship, build your ammo storage with too little armour and you'll get a spectacular explosion if you're hit in that area. You can customise missiles to be armour piercing to punch through like a needle or use high explosive to cause damage over a wide area, or even somewhere inbetween. You can make custom cannon turrets too, want dozens of tiny barrels firing like a shotgun or a mammoth cannon that takes 2 whole minutes to reload? Why not build 2 mammoth cannons bolted together?!

This is one of the best games i've played in a while, and new features, tweaks and mechanics are in the works making this a title that just keeps delivering.

Solid 9.75/10!!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm bit ambivalent about this game, to be honest. It's hard not to reccomend with a fully realized resource system, single-player campaign, regular updates, and a truly bewildering array of components that puts Space Engineers to shame. That said, it's also hard to reccomend this game, at least solidly, due to the many technical limitations.

Don't get me wrong, I'm aware that it's incomplete and that work hasn't been finished and that, given the track record so far coupled with my own personal (if limited) interactions with the developer, it's very likely that this WILL see a final release. That said, you can'y play it right on anything beyond a dedicated gaming rig. The preveiws would have you believe that it's a game that's filled with epic clashed on the sea, in the sky, and among the heavens beyond... AND IT IS! But... they can only be realized by machines that can handle that sort of thing, and since (as of yet) the game still runs on 32-bit, so no one on a moderately powerful lappy willl likely ever see them.

However! For those with machines that can run this game without slow-down or imcomplete fleet pop-in? It's a fantastic experience. Skies choked with missiles, the sea churning with explosions, blocks flying in every direction, lasers burning through armor, shields deflecting exploding shells. Guns, lasers, missiles, torpedoes, mines, aircraft, ballooncraft, ships of every description, AND WOODEN SPACE SHIPS! Incredible battles with meticulously crafted vehicles, where unprecedented customization finally passes the barrier of mere customization in games" and actually becomes ENGINEERING.

So
date: I have trouble recommending this game because not everyone can enjoy it as it should be enjoyed. But for those who can... get it. Get it now. WHY AREN'T YOU GETTING IT YET?!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A voxel engine RTS with elements of RPG done in first person wraped in what is likely the best ocean and sky physics engine in the industry. After spending hours of fun building ships and airplanes and maby even a few space vessel's includeing your own weapons and missile's down to the ammo they shoot and configuring you ai(or driveing it manualy) to fight the way you whant you will enter the campaign to see how they work only to find that not only is the campaign a massive and evolving battle but that you will have a lot to learn along the way.

After playing a little over 400 hours the building procces still hasent goten tireing or boring and (probably because building is so fun) i still have yet to get even to endgame in the campaign.

With a very responsive and efficient dev(team now) i hope to spend many more hours playing this game as possibly the last rts ill ever need(dont NEED vr rts's but that dosent mean i wont try them when they come around :P)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGreat game, decent amount of depth (no puns please) and i love the keyboard based building style, cant see why no one thought of it before, makes things so much tidier and faster once you get it down. That will be the theme for this game, should you decide to play it. Getting it down. You will spend every minute of playing this game getting something down. You will learn how to build an engine. How to build a ship. Realise both your ship and engine suck so hard, they should be called The Dyson Mk I. You will re-learn how to build an engine. You will put that engine into a new ship. You will build a cannon. Your cannon wont work. You will rage. You will learn how to build a cannon properly. You will realise now that this is the ultimate learning curve simulator of all time. You will play. All day. E'rry Day. Occassionally, you may speak to your family and be reminded that they seem like nice people. One day, you may get down the life-work-FTD balance. But it wont be any day in the next fortnight. The learning curve is real and its called From The Depths. 10/10 would re-design ship 15 times before having nervous breakdown and coming back tomorrow.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, my first game was in november, I bought it after watching a playthrough of 20 episode.
'FUN!' I said, i bought it.
I looked at the map and different than on the video.

And i stopped playing it for a while because i couldn't understand how the map worked.
Then i played it again, today. 2015-05-24...
Load a game, start on fortress, made a ramming boat like the guide said. 'Start with a ramming boat, it's the best boat you can make against the first enemy boats.'
So i went east. Found my first targets... 1 boat with 20 cannons on it...
And 3 flying bombers.

A ramming boat. Against aircraft.


They destroyed my boat.
I warped back to my fortress, start getting resources to make a new ship.

And again, same guys, but now they come to me...
Well now i got a cannon, right?

Well, they went ABOVE my fortress, where my gun can't aim.

And they destroyed my fortress. Lost an hour of my time playing this today.

And you know what? I recommend this game. Really.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my story of this game so far. I've owned the game for a very long time but never bothered to play the campaign since it confused me at the time. Well, i started playing it recently and know how to work most of the HUD in the campaign. this is my story of my struggle against the deep water guard.

I started off int he starting base doing the usual. Making the crappy engine much more efficient, armoring up the supply room, etc etc. well i decided to take my huskie ( my fast scouting ship ) out to find some deep water guard. i unfortunately  ran into their main force near the resource zone and tried to retreat. I failed and my huskie was a goner. i knew they would send that force to me so i build a rocket launcher that held 8 laser guided rockets and waited. Thankfully they only sent one plane and my rockets quickly dealt with it. I had more confidence and decided to build a semi expensive ( crystal wise) ship that i knew would help. I eventually built up a 6 ship fleet and decided to bring the fight to them. Short story short, i got slaughtered. i only had enough resources to build 2 ships. My small rocket plane and my rocket cruiser. i decided i would build another huskie and go scout some place since i had nothing else to do. ( i grabbed the resource zone that i mentioned earlier) i found 3 ships. They had a plunderer and 2 atlases coming for me. i decided  to lure them to my base and they destroyed both my fortresses. i reloaded my last save and decided to try taking out the plunder by destroying the ammo barrels. i rode my huskie into battle with a overpowering determination and i boarded the plunderer. i quickly punched my way to the core and destroyed it. i cheered in triumph and noticed my repair tentacles were repairing the ship, i panicked and checked the map only to realize that i captured the ship. I laughed and realized the ships gun systems were down till the core i destroyed came back to repair. i noticed the ship had plenty of repair bots and decided to man the guns myself till they were repaired. i started shooting the atlases with little affect. things were looking bad, with the ship being constantly hit by the atlases i thought i was doomed. Then, all of a sudden all the guns pointed the enemy balloon crafts and blew them out of the sky with little effort. i rode my newly captured ship back to base in excitement and knew, that the tides have turned against  the deep water guard.

100/10. ill never regret buying this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Score now: 9/10  Potential score: 10/10

Best early access I have ever encountered. Ever. I write this as my first decent attempt at a campaign fortress is slowly being ripped appart by the AI after disabling my weapons systems. I'm not even angry - just impressed that there is so much depth in this sandbox/strategy/vehicle builder game. Block by block construction is both simple and leads to intricate detail possibilities for construction. I agree with other reviews - research & planning is essential for this game if you want to enjoy it - and ends up being part of the fun.

There are numerous strategies that can be employed for the fleet & ship based fights - naval & air vehicles need to be allow for in this game. It lends itself toward letting the AI do everything in controlling ships/weapons however it is possible for the player to use both. I haven't tested out the fleet systems properly yet but going by the AI it looks to work fantastic - seriously the AI kicked my where it hurts with a pincer movement - then from above- seriously who attacks you from directly above????

Any lack of documentation is made up for by an incredibly supportive and involved community - the developer has obviously gone to much lengths to ensure that all learning styles are accounted for.

Replayability:
*If you are like me and love tweaking those designs just that *little bit more* and getting satisfaction from a good system, I can see it proving hours and hours of additional time.

*The current campaign is great for getting a feel for construction techniques and tactics to use in your own creations
*Not really a story based game - but why would you think that is what you are playing for

Pros
*Lasers
*Really, really big guns
*Customisable missile systems
*Smart/programable systems - seriously takes hours just to scratch the surface.
*Amazing tactical/strategic possibilities - I have not seen a game I would rate higher in this regard (I would love to see some tutorials on the map systems & maybe some more depth on campaign for this reason)
*Very customisable interface

Cons:
*Steep learning curve
*Requires a level of sophisication & engineering mindset to truly appreciate it. (Think minecraft bashing creeps with a sword to using automated traps to farm them) Not truly a con but may be a consideration for gifting.
*Some of the interfaces such as battle seem buggy (the intent is well documented but can be confusing when starting up)
**Very customisable interface - makes it difficult to remember what key map to press for certain situations (take this as an advisement if considering how much time you want to invest rather than a con.

Well recommended and cannot see what comes next as it develops. I only hope that the community gets behind it and allows it to continue to develop to its amazing potential.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For a game still grounded in its development, I find it to be highly addictive and fun, though somewhat frustrating, but that said, frustration is all part of a game.

The total creative freedom you have with the designer for the story mode and campaign is refreshing, but the modular aspects of putting your vehicle together can be daunting and requires sitting down and really tinkering around to find the right balance of armour, weaponry and other abilities. It is not just a pick up and play sort of game.

There are negatives naturally, the story mode isn't much good and with the game constantly being updated/developed, it does have stability issues. Nothing that wont be fixed in due course naturally.

In conclusion for this short review, I rate it 4 stars out of five, a great game to lose yourself in for a couple of hours.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Have you ever heard of learning curves? Yeah, this has a learning wall.

It's an incredibly hard game to get your head around. I strongly recommend watching an LP or lots of YT tutorials(TheBudkai's was good for me, although S1 will be very outdated now) if you want to play it.

Once you understand this game, it's amazing. Gameplay is very rewarding, especially watching your designs destroy (or get destroyed by) your enemies' designs. Building vehicles, their defenses, their propulsion, their weapons, is extremely in-depth.

It's pretty poorly optimized, but there should be an optimization update coming up soon according to the main dev. You need a good CPU to play, especially when you get further into the campaign. There's also lots of crashes (surprisingly few bugs considering the speed updates are churned out and the EA state), so make sure to save a lot.

The dev team are incredibly active, and clearly have an idea how the game will pan out.

Honestly, the biggest con is that you'll probably end up on the NSA's watchlist for googling so much about military weaponry.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The list shows more CONS than PROS, but I guess in the end the game is recommendable.

I give this game 7/10.

PROS
- Freedom to build (space) ships, planes, submarines and land vehicles.
- Lot of possibilities if you know how to program the AI.
- Worth your time and creativity.
- Fun to put designs to the test.

CONS
- Rather slow development.
- Physics are a bit strange sometimes. Some update seemed to have made some of my designs unplayable. If you want stable vehicles, you need to make them big. That's okay for most people, but I like to design historical planes with realistic sizes and proportions.
- Steap learning curve.
- UI is a bit messy and unattractive, or at least very unpolished.
- Needs high-end computer.
- Multiplayer could be better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Incredibly deep build-things-to-blow-things-up sandbox game.  Far better than other titles in this genre (some of which are little more than basic blocky vehicles in arena matches), boasting not only competetive play and casual sandbox play but also a number of preset scenarios to challenge your design, and a great big delicious campaign mode, which I've barely scratched (at >100 hours).

You can tell I just enjoy blowin' ♥♥♥♥ up trying to get that perfectly balanced, ordinance-spewing, sleek, sexy war machine.  SO MUCH LOVE.

I probably spend 95% of my time in the vehicle designer just making new things.. and things is the best word i can use to describe them.  Such variety, I have made submarines that lift out of the water and zoom into space.  Tanks that crawl on the ocean floor. Speedboats, Jet boats, Resupply boats, Cargo Boats, Anti-air boats, Missile boats, Torpedo boats, Laser boats, Fan boats, Sail boats, normal boats and all of them in various sizes and lethalities.  Fighters, Intercerptors, Airships with balloons, Thrustercraft, hovercraft, spacecraft, Surface Attack Aircraft, Torpedo Bombers, Cram Bombers and Regular bombers.

The point is..  if you want to build it, weaponize it and use it..  whatever 'it' may be.. then this is the game for you!

WAY WORTH IT!

Early Access Review

One week in and i just love this game.
If you like to build stuff - this game is for you - powerful designer allows to build anything and design it to your liking. Ships, planes, spacecraft for sure but also the engines, weapons and AI can all be designed to fit any requirement.
It takes a bit of time to learn but it's not overly complicated and it's a lot of fun.
A real gem imo.

Pros
- Excellent (the best?) designer / builder.
- Has depth but not overly complicated.
- Build everything - not just vessels but also weapons, engines and AI.

Cons
- Hurts social human relataions - builder so addictive i played almost 50 hours in just over a week.
- Non trivial learning curve (totally worth it though).
- UI could be better organized

Bottom line: totally worth every cent - even in alpha stage.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*EARLY ACCESS* - Game still in development

If you are into voxel building games (IE. Minecraft) and want a bigger focus on PVP then this game is for you. Much deeper and customize-able than games like Robocraft. While this game does have a fairly steep learning curve and Youtube tutorial videos are practically mandatory for some of the more complex designs like setting up your own AI control of your ships and building custom weapons once you get the hang of it the game is a blast. Anything from submarines, planes, and even space ships are possible in this game.

There are some features that really make this game stand out to me that I haven't seen done anywhere else like being able to design your own custom weapons and setup your own AI to control your individual ship or even your fleet. While there is a simple weapons" tab which includes prebuilt weapons like small and heavy cannons
recommended: and ramming weapons like rams and drills the real meat and potatoes is the Custom Cannons
hoursPlayed: Custom missiles/torpedoes
voteText: and laser weapons. Simple weapons work fine early on against smaller ships made of wood but don;t have the versatility or sheer damage custom weapons are capable of.\n\nCustom weapons aren't simply placed on a ship but have to be built using individual components. For example to build a cannon you start with the firing piece. Then you can add different types of barrels (recoil reduction
helpfulPercent: flash suppressed
votesHelpful: etc) and can add a component which increases the barrel gauge. Then you can add components like ammo crates
votesTotal: armor pen and explosive shells
votesFunny: autoloaders that speed up firing
commentsCount: shot predictors
column16: etc. These components all modify the weapon in certain ways like accuracy
column17: range
column18:
and dps. Custom missiles are built differently but the core idea still applies and same goes for the laser weapons.

At this point you have a great game where you can build some pretty awesome combat vehicles but they didn't stop there.
The feature that makes this game stand above most other voxel style games is the ability to create your own AI for your ships. Using an AI mainframe and a selection of different cards like target prioritization and Naval AI you can program your entire fleet or just individual ships to act autonomously within the rules you set for the ship. If you have a long range missile boat you could set it to try to stay within a certain range from its target. These are just the most basic AI functions and can get very deep and complicated depending on the design. This means not only can you create an entire fleet of ships with AI
column19: but you can create an enemy fleet using AI to do battle against. Campaign and story missions do a good job of showing this off in single player.\n\nMultiplayer is planned and the option is in game but is currently not implemented but should be soon."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Aright, so here's the thing. This is a great game IF you're willing to sink obsessive amounts of time into it. This is by no means a casual game as there is simply too much content to be absorbed across any number of ten minute sessions. If one isn't willing to make that committment to learning, this game is not for them.



Reasons to play this game:

+Excellent physics, especially for a voxel box-esque game.
+Build literally any sort of vehicle you want. You want a spaceship that doubles as a submarine? No problem.
+Story missions that test the depths of one's abilities.
+Fully customizable weapons platforms. I don't think of my laser guided missiles so much as missiles as they are long range sea mines that happen to fly.
+Intuitive and shockingly convenient vehicle automation.
+Nowhere as resource intensive as one would think it would be.

Reasons NOT to play this game:
-Steep learning curve. Building more than basic boats and engines is not for the faint of heart.
-High time commitment.
-Build interface is clunky and plays less like a game than a 3D drafting program.
-Controls frequently inconvenient and limited in customization.
-Stock vehicles for story missions seem unabashedly bad. Namely one critical, otherwise easily fixed flaw, like leaving the driveshaft of a gigantic drill completely exposed...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Epic. Just epic.

I tend to shy away from Early Access nowadays, given the recent disappointments like Starforge or Towns, but this definitely hit the sweet spot of EA.

The sheer scope of the premise, given with the activity and apparent competence level of the developer made this pretty much an instant buy. It also has a pretty good AI (one that even the player can use, too), so it offers a ton of replayability already. A campaign with resource gathering, diplomacy, hell even a working RPG system with levelups are there to tamper around with. Didn't even factor in things like multiplayer or co-op, which are still pretty much a work in progress.

Also, the physics are pretty nice. Recoil has an actual impact, parts breaking off of your vessel can make you lose control, and weight will make you sink to the bottom of the ocean, whereas airtight compartments on a metal ship will keep you afloat, unless breached and flooded with water.


If you like Kerbal Space Program or Starmade, or if you like the big, humming multiblock machines of certain Minecraft mods, you're probably going to love the hell out of this. Oh yeah, there's space, too. Orbital cannons raining down fiery death on submarines are possible and encouraged. And don't worry, the graphics are going to get an overhaul, too. Now stop reading and go buy the game D:

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBought the key for this game on another game selling site for 7 bucks less than here.  Learning to use the construction editor in this game is a bit of a challenge but not that bad.  And once you learn it, constructing things in this game is far easier and QUICKER than any other similar building game that I have!  Especially if you take the extra time to learn how to edit using the keyboard method as opposed to using the mouse method.  In a very short time, Ive constructed quite a large and stable hull complete with power train installed.  Next Ill focus on making the top side of the ship look cool.  Later Ill get into experimenting with my own engine builds and the like(right now Im using one of the games pre-fab engines).  If you are creative, like to design and build cool looking things that you can then test for functionality, and even get in battles with what you've created to see how it holds up, then this game is definitely a must have for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From the Depths is an extremely satisfying game. It is the perfect blend of all my favorite sandbox games. However, it is very complex, from designing your very own engine, to getting the thrust to weight ratio perfect, all the way to creating artifficial intelligence to control your weapons that you created.

Pros:

There is so much variety in this game, anything you want to do, you can.
Ample amounts of tutorials are at your fingertips, as a beginner I had no troubles learning how everything worked.
For an alpha game, it is suprising how optimized it is. I have not dropped below 60 fps once, even with large vehicle battles surrounding me.
You can create any sized vehicle as long as you design it correctly. From 4 x 4 rafts, to 300+ x 300+ Airships.
All of the controls and graphics are 100% customizable, so you can have the perfect game experience.
The developers have been great at constantly updating this game, I am certain this won't be the same sell & run" experience that we get with so many early access games. (DayZ
recommended:
etc.)

Cons:

The multiplayer is not yet developed
hoursPlayed: but the developers say they will be coming out with a fully functional multiplayer.\nTo the faint of heart

votesHelpful: and it has only been out for around a single month. Give this game a shot
votesTotal:
for $20 you can't get anything better.

Final Rating: 9/10
Note: This will be 10/10 with the finished multiplayer."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Have you ever designed a kick-♥♥♥ sailboat in Minecraft and wish you could take to the seas with it? Have you ever thought Kerbals were too peaceful? Have you ever wanted to design a plane that used cannons as a means of movement? Me neither, but in From the Depths, YOU CAN!

From the Depths is a sandbox physics game with some rts elements thrown in for good measure. Build a ship, watch it sink. Build a better ship, one that moves! ....Then watch it get blown up. Build a gun, then build a ship around it! This is, in essence, what FtD is all aboot.

In career mode you can take your designs and put them to the test. Capture resource nodes, battle pirates, and build your empire. Switch from game view to map view and position your fleet. Instead of rolling the dice when two ships meet, go back into physics mode and battle your enemy head on. You can manually control your vehicles and bases, or you can use the modular AI pieces and build an AI to do it for you.

Speaking of modular, this game features modular engines, cannons, lasers, missiles, etc. Instead of placing a gun block where you want a gun, you can build your cannon from many modules that altar how the gun works. Range, reload time, damage, armor penetration, explosive rounds, accuracy, etc.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI haven't had many games that captured my interest as this one has. Sure, it isn't a finished product, but you can build stuff, and then customize the heck out of whatever you just built, and then build on your customizations with further modifications. I like games that allow you this kind of freedom. It's the type of game that says you can have as many guns, and as much armor as you like. You'd better be prepared to have your hopes and dreams dashed if it's poorly set up, however. Oh, I haven't mentioned the developer yet. He's an amazing guy, active in the community, gives feedback on suggestions/bug reports, etc. Too few games nowadays can boast that as well.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game runs in the vein of others such as kerbal space program, starmade and space engineers. The difference being it is heavily focused on combat and fleets of units rather than a single craft. It has a steep learning curve so it can be daunting at first although there are quite a few videos and guides out there to help you on the more complicated things. The satisfaction from getting your fleet afloat and firing a hail of cannon shells and missile streaking towards the enemy is akin to glee as you watch the enemy fleet explode into little bits.

Somewhere between a simulator, rts and a fps all rolled into one, its not for everyone, but for those with a creative streak its a highly addictive mix. For those with less patience they can always use the vehicles created by others from the workshop or FTD forums to get straight into the action.

Once the co-op campaign is finished I doubt there will be any other game I'd rather play than From The Depths for a long time

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is awesome.
Build your own ships, planes, helicopters, submarines, sattalites, fortresses, VTOLs, aircraft carrierers, etc with a hugely customizable array of blocks.

The game allows you to custom tune your engines, weapons, armor, etc. to perform a certain way and almost every design choice has advantages and drawbacks.

The developer, Nick Smart, is very helpful and dedicated to improving the game.
There are updates every week, unless Nick is working on a huge feature.

The building mode is very well thought out and is as efficient as possible. Vehicles can be 10,000+ blocks in some cases, so the mirror line, fill tool, and pre-fabs are essential. The optional keyboard based building mode can be significantly faster than the traditional point and click mouse building mode.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After logging about 10 hours game time, mostly just designing BOATS THAT FLIP OVER AND SINK VERY EASILY, I finally started playing the campaign.

This game seems to be the most detailed RTS concievable.  Build your units block by block if you want to.  Build your resource collecting block by block too.  Build engines and tinker how many cylinders, how many crankshaft sections, where to place carberators, more suerchargers or more local fuel tanks etc.  Listen as the torque capacity goes up and the RPMs go down!

Warning: The learning curve is rather large.  There are still non-intuitive parts of the interface.  For example, if you try to put a gun together, you might have components that aren't contributing anything just because of where they are placed, and I'm still learning to master these nuances.  Looking at a block shows whether it's connected, but it doesn't glow or somehow make it more obvious at a glance - you have to double check.

Same for engines - it's a balancing act swapping out a supercharger for a fuel tank to see if the power capacity goes up in unforseeable ways.  Maybe eventually this will all make sense (like an aha!  that's because there was only 1 carberator there and not 2!") - but right now for me it's all very mysterious and fun.  :)

Another Warning:

The build mode also has a concept of what is being editted
date: which isn't clarified by the tutorials that I had gone through
recommended: so if you want to change a gun in the middle of changing the ship
hoursPlayed: I was scratching my head why it wouldn't let me place blocks for the longest time before it made sense.\n\nI'm sure I have not fathomed everything possible in this game
voteText:
but it is meting out a great feeling of satisfaction discovering all it has to offer.

--- FINAL WARNING ----
The game really does move heavily in the direction of "serious games".  These are games which try to simulate real world problems.  You can program Lua scripts in FTD

votesFunny: rather than in the game....  your mileage may vary.  :)  Chin up!\n\nAlso have a look at the very detailed models available in the workshop.  There are 1:1 ratio replicas of historical battleships and ...  lots more."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From the Depths, a sandbox where you are a lone war-machine tasked with defeating the many factions on the world. Not all are hostile, with there being diplomacy, you are able to bribe to distract the enemy or become allies. Many refer to you as the enemy, with the goal to erase them all from existance and claim dominance over the planet of Neter.

You make your ship from scratch, fitting it with an AI if you need to, efficient engines for power and of course, arnament, ranging from your average pea-shooter to a 500mm cannon able to shoot High explosive rounds up to 5 kilometers away, or your huge ICBM like missiles that shred the enemy from a safe distance.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I initially gave this game a bad review. I regret that now.

The time willingly put into playing this game makes up for the price paid. Therefor I know that players who enjoy constructing war machines of all kinds will enjoy this. So far the ship I've made floats and is agile after the second construction - that's more than can be said for the 20+ flight tests you go through on Kerbal Space Programme. It functions, and in that sense it isn't hard.

I simply wish the learning curve wasn't as steep in other ways. For example, I still don't really understand the mechanics behind custom cannons and other complexset-ups, even with tutorials. This could be on account of my own stupidity, but in a way I would prefer simpler options that produce the same results or at least a simple pictorial diagram of a simple, working set-up (like my dads old haynes manuals from the 90's - for the primitive man).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game will brutally beat you over the head with its learning curve until you are lying helpless and bereft of hair on your keyboard. You will cry, you will scratch your head, you will watch tens of hours of youtube tutorials and let's plays, you will burn out google's servers trying to find a solution to your very specific niche problem. I assure you, your efforts are futile.

BUT

If you put in the effort, if you make the commitment, if you can see how much potential this game really has, your blood, your sweat, and your tears will be rewarded in ways no words can describe. Ever orbited your first probe in Kerbal Space Program? Ever completed the entire Besiege campaign with a single design? Ever survived your first winter in Don't Starve? Ever beaten a long standing record in Super Hexagon? These are the feelings of elation you will receive when your first little ship stays afloat and is balanced, when it takes its first little strides all on its AI driven own, when it takes control of that gun and uses it effectively against a target, when you win your first battle in the campaign.
These and many more glorious moments will be yours, friend.
If you have the time, the will and the intellect, this game is worth every bitcoin.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is NOT a minecraft clone.  It stands alone as a brilliant game in a very different genre.  If you ever enjoyed building legos as a child, you need this game.  If you ever loved designing ships in Master of Orion, you need this game.  Imagine if your built something with legos, programmed it, and then it began shooting at other legos, built by other people.

The AI shines in this game.  I would never fire my own guns, though I have the option to, as the AI is simply a better shot.  Countless games that allow massive creative freedom lack any sort of 'challenge'.  Not so in FtD.  Enemy designs are hugely varied and hugely dangerous.  This game provides 4 singleplayer campaigns, resource limits and gathering, and multiple faction that can battle each other.  Designing a single turret can be very satisfying, and there is a lot of skill that goes into designing ships that are effective.

Did I mention that you can build submarines, planes, functional helicopters, and even spacecraft?  And your spacecraft can shoot at planetbased targets?

Now, the game is good, it's entirely worth the full cost, but it is alpha.  It's a very complete alpha, but there is clearly polishing still to do.  Optimization and balancing is needed, though the game is very playable and very fun currently.  Shield generators are OP at the moment, for example.  I am incredibly pleased to have bought this game, and I hope to see more people buying it, and a wonderful future for it.

The ships are both durable and fragile at times, with armor and materials playing a very realistic role.  Ships can be blown in half, but they can also take 10 minutes of solid pounding.  Everything is built into the game.  If a shell hits your ammo stores, it can gut the ship, or it can do very little if you designed to prevent a chain reaction.  Everything has tradeoffs.  The very AI that controls your ships is built on your ships, and pieces of it can be blown up.

Unlike most early access games, this game would be worth the price even if it there was never another update.  I would be very sad if that happened, but I wouldn't want a refund, because I'd still want to be playing the game.  I can give no higher praise.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Quite a good block-based building game. Although the game's genre is focused on naval battles, you can build ground vehicles if you so wish. You can create various weaponry for different roles: Flak cannons for your battleships; CRAM cannons for your artillery; or LUA-guided missiles for Air-to-Air, Air-to-Ground or vice-versa. There are wheel blocks for land-based vehicles, but they are highly neglected, and I hope they are worked on soon; as you can create some stunning tanks with various shell types that will surely catch the interests of many War Thunder players, such as myself.

Pros:
A vast selection of parts ranging from lightweight metal alloys and ERA armour to LUA script for AI mainframes and various cannon types for both beginners and professionals.
Stable multiplayer capability, although some bugs should be ironed out, such as the lack of Prefabs and host-only barrel-number selection for advanced cannons.

Cons:
You need a good graphics card to run this game over 30 fps at 1080p. I had around 15 on 720p with my old GT 620 (came with my prebuilt computer), now I get 60fps on 1080p at high.

All-in-all a fun build game for Land, Air, and Naval vehicles.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This block based, build anything you like combat simulator is better than sliced bread with peanut butter and jelly.

I mention peanut butter and jelly because this game isn't just the bread, but comes with a metric s**t ton of hidden features that will amaze the armchair war machine engineer for days, weeks and months.

From Age of Sail frigates to Space Battleship Yamato, build every darn war machine you've ever dreamed of in childhood and make them dominate subsurface, sea, air, land, and space battles with your arsenal of custom designed guns, lasers and missile systems that are near fully customizable. Anything is possible, prepare to be amazed by the hundreds of example ships packaged in the singleplayer missions, they're absolutely dangerous and creative, from submarine rams to paddle boats to flying fortresses and laser armed behemoths that ascend far beyond human engineering.

And all that from a small selection of Minecraft style blocks!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From the Depths (FtD) is a game I highly recommend to people who like a learning curve in their games. This is a kind of game where you can show off your skill and power to your friends because you put in the time and effort to master the game. If you are a lazy person who likes playing games like Call of Duty just because they are easy, don't get this game. The game itself is a pretty interesting sandbox game where you can build ships, fortresses, planes, and even land vehicles. Most of the game revolves around the ships (hence the name, From the Depths) which all have main components like engines, propellers, rudders, AI cores, weapons systems, and etc. Each of these components will need to be learned individually and will function together to make your ship. The game allows for a lot of customization with its parts.  I think that this game really shows what you can be capable from learning from a game. I highly recommend this game to anyone who is interested.

-TheNileCroc07

[EDIT] By the way, the achievement of completing the first tutorial is broken for me. If anybody else has this problem, please tell me in the comments.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Prepare for mass rage and rage quits.

I love this game, I've only played about ~20 hours but I've learnt a fair bit. The learning curve is like getting hit in the face with a bowling ball. If you are going to buy the game prepare to do countless hours of research on how to play the game.

The game itself has one simple objective, destroy the opposition; Simple right? Well it is if you know how to construct might war ships and planes whilst also keeping an eye out for enemy fleets and keeping an eye on your own. Distrubuting resources left right and centre and all sorts of multitasking that I cannot perform because I'm just simple minded.

But if you know how to play your cards, and can learn the fundementals quickly then you're going to have 100s of hours of just pure fun bombarding with every missile, cannon and railgun you can muster. At the end of the day its just another war game but in my view it is one that stands out above every other war game because of just how unique it is.

I could go on explaining the pros the cons and every detail inbetween but I think I've said enough to show how good it is.

10 Kitkats out of 10

Absolutly love this game, i have over 360 hours on it, defiintly one of the best games ive ever played. Its many building options works for all diffrent styles, wether you like sci fi super ships, or want just realism, its perfect for both. The game also has constant updates which always freshens up the game. This game is also is very complciated and takes a while to really get the hang of, but when you do, its awesome. Extreme learning curve. It actually takes a little inteligence to be good at this game, or at least a lot of playing time. Great game, if you like building anything your mind can come up with, this game is for you. I highly recomend this game.

Pros
Tons of Building Options
Cool Campaign
You can build anyting you can think of.
Constant new features

Cons
Only thing is the rapid degrading of FPS when using more than one huge ship

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game definitely is aimed to the audience, who love voxel, sand box, experimenting and engineering games types, but yet with demanding learning curve. It may appear at beginning this game is difficult to handle, but once you get into it, it is so much fun. There is plenty of tutorials available for new and old comer, on the official forum http://fromthedepthsgame.com/forum/ on Youtube, Steam and what is interesting, in game itself.

So what you can do? Well actually A-Lot...
1. You can play in creative mode, building your own designs, structures, fortress, vehicles (submarines, naval ships, air ships, space ships, or any of mix of them and more)
2. You can play campaign, fight against AI driven factions (player made vehicles), in form of RTS, or/and FPS, while you can develop your own designs and forces, as long you got enough resources.
3. Test your own designs against your, or other players' designs.
4. Making your designs to behave, as desired, which may be challenging.
5. Design your own weapon systems, both offensive and defensive.
6. Setup your vehicles and weapon system AI behaviours.
7. Experiment with anything, you got access to.
8. Making block" art.
9. And whatever else your imagination allow to ..
10. Download and share your designs with the community
date: on Steam and main forum.\n11. Share and gain experience with community\n12. Join player hosted tournaments and test your secret design against other contestants. Results are tend to be uploaded to youtube. For example by TheBudkai
recommended: but not only (youtube channel) https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLmkTaK7E7RJouOrgdGANTTna-_5J6fVYL\n13. On main forum

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Absolutely fantastic. 10/10. Early access done right.

From the Depths, despite its blocky appearance, is a startlingly original game. From the construction features to the customizable combat AI, almost everything in From the Depths is innovative, exciting, and easy to use. In practice, many games in the construction genre tend to fall flat in certain areas. Unlike these, From the Depths is already well optimized, intuitive, and fun. From the Depths construction mechanic is unique, allowing extremely complex ideas to be easily realized. Unlike space engineers and many similar construction games, FTD's construction system is fluid, polished, and robust. Creating complex vehicles such as airships and battleships is easy enough- play the game, familiarize yourself with the mechanics, and boom! There you have it. That's all the experience you need to build something cool in From the Depths. Building something that works really well, however, is more difficult. The good news is, you'll never runout of ideas because From the Depth's extremely in-depth armor and weapons mechanics allow for hundreds of viable strategies.  Hollow armor designed to absorb enemy damage and insulate the core systems? Check. A floating reactor, relying on its powerful shields to rain death from above? Check. A wooden sailboat? Check. Several hundred wooden sailboats? Double check. Combat itself is no less impressive. The AI works surprisingly well out of the box. Because vehicles in From the Depths rely on many individual systems to continue working, combat in From the Depths is always dynamic and interesting. Aircraft usually rely on their speed to outrun danger, casting their lot on large engines and light armor. Landing a hit on an aircraft's jets is often enough to send them into a tailspin. Knock out the engines, and the battle's already won. Target a craft's radar and sensors, and leave a battleship blind. If you're brave enough, it's possible to go one step further and knock out a ship's master AI control. Target the propellers with torpedoes, and leave your enemies paralyzed. The possibilities are quite literally endless. When played In first person, From the Depths can become a fantastic roll-playing game. Ignoring the campaign, From the Depths is a fantastic sandbox. Ignoring the construction, From the Depths is a damn good action-RPG.

What I'm trying to get across here is that From the Depths is fun. Like, really fun. Everything works, and the price is right.
Do yourself a favor and buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm pretty new to Steam, So many people would probobly ignore this review.
That out of the way I give Ftd 10/10
From the Depths is why I joined the Steam community. (As Nick, The Awesome dev behind this marvel, Moved it to Steam)
The Amazing thing about this game is there are HUNDREDS of blocks and modules, each with there respective purpose and resource cost. This makes me willing to spend countless hours creating the most efficient design possible.
But Alas, Not one design can be all that. So I'm forced to create many vehicles each with an intended role. I have A bomber, An oil drill ship, A mining and salvage drillship, An anti air patrol craft and most of all my personal fleet of war machines with my signature command battlecruiser.
Interestingly enough it is just as fun building the ships as pioleting them as you have to endure trials where you realize Oh god noooooooooooooo......."  if you happened to forget an engine on your tiny attack fighter and "HOLY SH** THATS AWESOME" If you were lucky enough to discover a great use for the many components. I often find myself loading up vehicles that were made by other players just to test how well my design would hold up.
All in all the main attactivness of the game is theres no one to tell you what to do
date: Build whatever you wan't It dosn't matter if its not combat effective
recommended: The pure graphics and construction alone can inspire great awe. (As The giant chicken somone made did for me)\n\nSo if you have a spare $20
hoursPlayed: and a steam account then this game is perfect for you\nIf you don't have $20 then its still perfect you just need to save up :P"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Basically, when I first saw the game on YouTube, I didn't expect too much. I just bought it to have some fun with other peoples desings.
As I tried to build my firs little vehicle I struggled with engine desing, guns, controls.
To be honest, I had no Idea. But after a few hours of building you really know what to do, learn how to build engines and gianormous cannons.
At first the build-mode is a bit unusual in comparison to games like Minecraft or Robocraft. After a short time you'll figure out how genious it is. You can build even huge vehicles very fast.
The phisics are really good.

Short and sweet: It is one of the best alpha-games I ever played, till now I only encountered one bug! Of course, some content may still be missing, but all in all it's really addicting. (Not sure if thats good or bad ;))

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOne of the best block based vehicle builders, well, ever. UI is clunky, game is very taxing (I can barely run it), and the learning curve is a bit steep. Most of the negative reviews are people who played the game for less than an hour and said they couldn't figure out how the game worked, or they didn't like the UI so they gave up. UI is odd, yes, but again, you get used to it, and it works in the end. It's not a bad game because you can't figure out how it works.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not just-another-build-and-fight, this actually does a pretty good job in the physics department.

Basically you can design a land, sea, air and/or spacevehicle (literally all 4 of em at once is quite the challenge), move it around and fight other players, or have AI control it and play it as though it were an RTS.

Resource collection, build and supply vehicles, fight, design your own guns, engines and all that, all thats missing is what some would call atmospherics, dynamic fluids, pipes, electrical grids and the likes, but that may just destroy this whole concept...Sorry, just missing that in todays games, too much focus on multiplayer at the expense of engineering aspects...but thats just my personal.

At the moment it is still in alpha and it's noticable; It demands a lot from ones computer unless you limit yourself to the editor or a campaign. Doing missions is quite impossible for me at the moment. Since some technology can only be unlocked in missions there are some things I simply cannot use.

Great concept, reasonable implementation, but at the moment has some serious performance issues which will (hopefully) be resolved in the next couple of updates. As always, looking forward to seeing more on this project.

On a sidenote, I may have been somewhat inconsistant in my recommendations about this specific game. I am sorry for that, it may create confusion and some people may judge me for that, and that is fine. I write these reviews based on my experiences with the project it involves, and in this case I have had faith in the development of this project, lost it, and now regained it.

I maintain quite a few reviews, and usually after playing the game it involves for a while. For those who have seen my library it would not take much to understand why it can take a long time before I return to a previous review and check if it still applies. I do check them occasionally, but rarely find myself rewriting or editing one.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The good:

+ Many types of blocks to use, infinite options in creating whatever the hell you want
+ Color Palette to select that exact shade of black you want for your 10billion RP battleship
+ Rough but pretty well set up Multiplayer support
+ Pretty damn good soundtrack for an alpha
+ Skill points to level your character in both SP + MP
+ Unique sandbox concept that works out quite well
+ Doesn't crash when loading unlike some other big AAA games
+ Linux/SteamOS

The not so good:
= Could use some better SFX
= Intense lag with many blocks (probably will be worked out later)
= Bit buggy on inputs, but not that bad / gamebreaking

The Ugly:
- go look at something else pleb

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Many reviews for this game come frome people with around an hour of play time, these reviews mostly complain about the following:
1) The game is too complicated, as I couldn't master it in 15 minutes.
2) The UI sucks. (Fair enough, it's not great. Shouldn't be a reason to stop playing altogether.)
3) Tutorials aren't that detailed.

I'm going to address 1 and 3.

1) The game is very complicated, it is hard to learn, and you will often find yourself getting destroyed by even the early enemies. This does not merit a bad review, if anything, it deserves a good one. A game like this should be complicated, it should be difficult and should reward those who put time and effort into the game. If a game like this was simple, in which you would go around, editing pre-made hulls, with pre-made guns, fighting scripted battles with no control over your craft, would you play it? Of course not!
If you want to play this fantastic game, spend some time playing it and watch some tutorials. If you give up this game after an hour of playing it, you are throwing away a gem of a game.

2) Yes, the tutorials are not great, they are not very detailed and can often leave new players confused. However, this game is still in ALPHA. These tutorials will grow more detailed as the game progresses and if you can't wait for this to happen, there are plenty of more detailed tutorials on YouTube and guides on Steam.

So, in conclusion, buy this game! You won't regret it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now, while this game has its hangups, it's improving rapidly (for an early access game) and I heartily recommend it. my advice is to steal ships at first, reverse engineer them, give up and make a fortress with a giant ♥♥♥♥ off gun on it.

EDIT: new story for a marauder I was.... improving.
So I wanted to use it as a cargo ship, but it was too slow.
Solution: strap around 25 ion thrusters to it
But it wasn't going fast enough, despite the sheer number of thrusters
so I noticed the ship didn't have strong enough engines to power all those things.
I figured since it was so slow, just leave the throtle on while I worked, and so I go to town, making a really strong engine. I finish and look up.....
and I'm about half way to orbit, upside down.

Accidental Kerbal space program/10

Most of the negative reviews are people who played the game for less than an hour and said they couldn't figure out how the game worked, or they didn't like the UI so they gave up. UI is odd, yes, but again, you get used to it, and it works in the end. It's not a bad game because you can't figure out how it works.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Many reviews for this game come frome people with around an hour of play time, these reviews mostly complain about the following:
1) The game is too complicated, as I couldn't master it in 15 minutes.
2) The UI sucks. (Fair enough, it's not great. Shouldn't be a reason to stop playing altogether.)
3) Tutorials aren't that detailed.

I'm going to address 1 and 3.

1) The game is very complicated, it is hard to learn, and you will often find yourself getting destroyed by even the early enemies. This does not merit a bad review, if anything, it deserves a good one. A game like this should be complicated, it should be difficult and should reward those who put time and effort into the game. If a game like this was simple, in which you would go around, editing pre-made hulls, with pre-made guns, fighting scripted battles with no control over your craft, would you play it? Of course not!
If you want to play this fantastic game, spend some time playing it and watch some tutorials. If you give up this game after an hour of playing it, you are throwing away a gem of a game.

2) Yes, the tutorials are not great, they are not very detailed and can often leave new players confused. However, this game is still in ALPHA. These tutorials will grow more detailed as the game progresses and if you can't wait for this to happen, there are plenty of more detailed tutorials on YouTube and guides on Steam.

So, in conclusion, buy this game! You won't regret it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From the Depths is perfect for people who want to build and test things for their own reasons and a lot less perfect for people who want a game with a clear objective or progression system.

Nothing new here for a sandbox game; people complaining that there isn't anything to do, just because they didn't go LOOKING for something to do, forgot to take a look at the tags under the description of the game. If you DO go looking for things to do, you'll find that there are, in fact, meaningful things to do with your creations, such as:

- Entering them into a tournament;
- Playing through the campaign using them;
- Playing through the story missions using them;
- Creating a custom campaign filled with them.

Not to mention the possibility of creating custom LUA AI code for the vehicles you make. There's potential for hundreds, no, thousands of hours of fun here. For only 20 euros at the time of writing, that's a much better deal than a thousand hours of film, a thousand hours of lecture/literature, a thousand hours of other games... you name it.

Of course, to get so much out of the game, you'll need to do some work yourself, too. Not only will you have to look for things to do (tournaments, custom campaigns, etc.), but you will also have to learn to play the game. I must warn you: learning to create all the possible vehicle types and making them work well took me a good 200 hours, if not more. This means you have to be prepared to learn. And by learning, I mean learning through trial and error.

The learning experience, however, is fun. That alone would be enough of a reason to recommend this game, but the best part of the game very definitely is this: building your creations, of whatever kind you choose*, for whatever purpose you choose**, at whatever time you choose: there's a great deal of freedom and a lot to do here.

*Submarines, boats, helicopters, airplanes, hovercraft, spacecraft, fortresses, hydrofoil surface-skimmers, completely unrealistic flying behemoths, land vehicles with jet engines because wheels don't work yet...

**The campaign, story missions, custom campaigns, tournaments...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So today I thought that I would write another review, and I thought I would do it on a game that I recently have really quite enjoyed, From The Depths. This game is for sure complex when first starting out on it and it has a large learning curve, but once it is mastered, it is a hella lot of fun. Basics of it is building your own vehicle, such as a boat, airship, plane, submarine, almost anything you want and then it gets raided by AI armies. Another great feature is that you can build your own cannons/turrets and customize them however you want. You can make it deal massive amounts of damage or have a crazy firing speed. It is so amazing how you can create such a variety of things from just a single block. I 100% recommend this game to those with a creative mind and are looking for loads of fun!
