reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overview                                                                                                                                                            Brilliant game, its not hugely expensive. Its fun, creative,interesting.  it still has some content to come, but in terms of current content, this game really does have some serious replay value. I've owned the game for a little while, and i will admit, most people will find the game every difficult at first, but after a while you can slowly get used to the complex mechanics and parts involved when building in from the depths.

Building boats is surprisingly easy, as in, a slow , small, lightly armoured, lightly armed cruiser. But as you play you can really build glorious things. Im now starting to make space platforms, and slightly more advanced vehicles.


Weapons
Alas, some of my favourite parts of from the depths. Unlike most games on the market, you engineer your own weapons of destruction using complex and simple tools. Simple weapons are for those just starting, already made, work normally, all you need is ammo and some space, then you can branch out. Cram cannons are surprisingly simple for how powerful they are. launch explosive 50 pound shells, or build a piercing machine gun. Missiles, pretty much do what it says on the tin, plus a bit of what seeking and some fancy tricks. lasers, helpful for more than mayhem, anti-ballistic properties.
advanced cannons, for , i quote experienced people with too much time on their hands".

performance
it dosen't lag unless your doing something really bad. movement is smooth
date:
so on.Not much else to say.

This game is cheap

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In short great idea for a game advanced block building and for those with patience and understand that things can get complex.

First I will say about this game is that it is still in Alpha and you are looking at early access. This means there are bugs and not polished. But the gameplay is there and it does work.
The game is regualrly updated and the Dev is responsive to players comments and issues as long as he knows there is an issue.
The biggest tip I could give anyone is get on the officail forums and you will find a community willing to help and responsive to any issues you may have. If you don't tell anyone about tyour problems don't moan when they don't get fixed for you.

Overall the building of ships with a physics implementation is a great idea and means that some very complex designs can be built by players. Then being able to pit that design against other peoples or the game created design makes you feel fabulous when your designs win.

Checkout the varoious youtube videos on this game for tutorials and helpful hints.

My own Video review of this game is below.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uDDIdSwOqqI

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game! I have spent nearly 30 hours on the game so far, and that is me just derping about in the builder menu! AI is good, although I have noticed that they always seem to shoot for the players robot, and with a bit of work that can be exploited, but that is me just nit picking as it is an alpha. Building in this game is very easy, once you get the hang of it. I was used to building games like Minecraft and Kerbal space program, so I was initially off put by the building interface. However, once I got the hang of it I could build rather complex boats with out too much work, it was that powerful. The ability to save chunks of craft, like turrets and engines you spent 7 minuets designing, then paste them later is an amazing tool that I have only seen in Kerbal Space program. My one real criticism is that this game, as befitting is complexity and depth, does have a bit of a learning cliff. Luckily there are good video tutorials online, including some made by the devs. I have seen betas and even full games that are less complete then this. And the fact that there have been 3 smallish but very useful updates in the last month,  makes this one of the best games of the year.

TL:DR  amazing game once you get into it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I dont think i could reconmend this game enough. Currently one of my favorites. The learning curve is incredibly difficult and even after 200+ hours i still struggle with making effective aircraft and airships but this is also what makes this game good as there is still something you can learn after so many hours. The advanced cannons are amazing once you figure them out and with the planned updates the developer has I feel they will be quite balanced. The developer is incredibly commited and squashing bugs that are posted on the forums in matter of days. The community in my experience is also very positive and offers tips without putting your designs down. The AI to start with is incredibly easy to use and understand to make your ships work and then with the introduction of lua and PID controllers if you know what your doing you can make them more effective.

If you pick up this game, expect to put time into it before you build something that doesnt get wrecked easily. my best tips i can give for starting out is pay attention to center of mass and try to have it below water line for ships. Learn the advanced cannons and watch irelan's and rugers tips for building them. Missles/torpedos for starting are also very good.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game so far, and the process/progress so far that has been done by this developer.

Very rarely do you get a developer that actually responds to suggestions. This game alone can be considered a gem for that reason in my opinion.

The game itself is a voxel style build e'm up. You can literally build anything from spaceships, submarines, battleships, helicopters, hot air baloons, and more, as is evident in the game description. As long as it makes sense in terms of physics, and common sense, you can build it.

Admittedly, the game is very complex. Most get turned off by the ammount of completely this game has (as you can tell by the majority of negative reviews). I admit, I was too. Uninstalled the game after about 2 hours of trying and failing to build a dinghy. Came back to it a month later, and haven't stopped since.

The designer mode, for me at least is where most of the game is, as I like to play around with the mechanics of the game, especially since they change almost every other day on the dev test build which I'm subscribed to.

The campaign mode is relatively simple, but pretty fun. At the moment, just kill everyone" to win. It takes a quite long time to do this

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is neither an easy nor forgiving sandbox, but if you make a point to stick with it and learn the fundamentals of the game the rewards worth it.   As I write this review it is still an early access game but shows promise as it continues to grow and expand.

If you think it is fun putting your creations into a skirmsh  with various opponents and see how they thrive or fail inspiring you to improve on your designs or create better ones from scratch.   You'll have to learn all you can at making efficient and effective designs if you want to surive and not break the resource bank.   Making vehicles that compliment each other and work together is crucial and challenging and expect to spend lots of hours learning by doing.

When starting out I'd recommend watching videos on youtube and understanding how things fit together it's not very intuitive and there are some thing you simply need to know before you set out.  The In-game tutorial is helpful as a leap off point but you'll still want to study others designs either on the workshop or those placed by the developers in game to get get an idea of 'how do they make this work?' and go from there.

Test and retest, trial and error is key here, don't expect to master things in a day or a week even, there are so many possibilities and generally if you can think it you can build it, the big question usually is if you should.

The only gripe I had is that he interface/controls take a lot of getting used to and feel clunky to me, but you can remap keys and such to something more to your liking but there is still room for improvement and as it is still in development I am sure it willl there have already been strides in this regard so I have high hopes for it.

This game may not be for everyone but if you like sandboxes to play in this certainly fits the genre and is worth a look.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let's start it out,

This game is VERY Complex, and take some time to learn, but there are always people and  ways to learn how to make parts work.  The depth of creation is steadily growing as more and more  parts are added in, and new tricks are constantly learned.

Cannons are fun to tinker with, and feel like the most  effective weapon to start with- They are  slightly more complex than missiles, but less taxxing and complex than Lazers. Currently there is no limit to the cannons other than Ammo type,  which is sadly set at just HE and AP for right now. But dont mis understand me- AA turrets are achieveable with high elevation cannons,  and extremely rapid fire.  Sadly until Flak is done its Rather Inneffective.

Missiles. The Kill-all-find-all  Alternative.  They are basic to start, with missile  settings to create your own missiles- this leads to Huge possibilitys, such as createing Torpedos, mines, depth charges,  even Bunker-Busters.    They can be made Very over powered however at 6 - 8 blocks, where they are the most effective size. but Cruise missiles with high fuel, fins, and targeting parts are possible aswell- just not as fun as the smaller missiles can actually Hit aircraft.

Lazers. Sci-Fi Death ( Now With better Accuracy than Storm Troopers!)  VERY Power hungry, but potentially the most damageing weapons with the quickest responce time- The only downside being its cost to make an Effective lazer.     But Atleast they dont miss! (Often)

Thats just a brief Tease on what you can find inside- If your a builder, test your skills, and join us!

Early Access Review

This game has absolutely blown me away. I'll admit it's difficult to learn at first, but well worth it. I can't get over how much there is to this game and it is still only in Alpha. I absolutely can not wait for more features.
This game just makes sense. Most creating games there is no reason for building a fortress or a ship or anything. This game gives you a reason, and the better your creations are the easier life is for you. I love the fact that you don't have to spend all day contantly repairing or building the same thing over and over. You design a ship or a part, copy and paste. Improve it, save over it. Repeat. I think the only thing this game needs now is a research tree. So much fun, and so much potential for more already!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's pretty damn hard to get started if you want any kind of working machinery. Once you understand it a bit better and get used to it, you can make some crazy contraptions.

I'm being kind of traditional (lazy?) and sticking to ships for the moment. Going crazy with those missile launchers, tho.
So much fun to see 10 or 20 them fire in series and strike a target.

Now, something I disliked a lot was the fact that you need to level up in practice mode before you can enter the campaign. I guess it serves the purpose of making sure you know how to fight, and it's good that you don't have to do a tutorial every time you do the campaign, but the learning tools seem a bit crazy to me (a 1+hour youtube video? Really?)

Now, there are also text and interactive tutorials, however the interactive ones kinda zip by so fast that I had to re-do the AI training a few times in order to figure out how to automate a gun.

So far, sandboxing is a lot of fun. I'd rather the freaking flying units to be a little easier to understand, tho.

----
An incredibly, INFURIATING part of the game is that, when your stuff is in combat, EVERYTHING ELSE GETS PHASED OUT. This includes your repair dock entering combat while it's repairing your combat ship.
Guess what happens? Your dock goes into combat while your combat ship phases out, entering a 500 second cooldown. If your dock has a minimum amount of guns, YOU'RE SCREWED.

Another frustrating thing that seems to happen is that the AI seems to have first pick in the spawn order.
Meaning that, if you have set a limit value of 20,000, the AI can spawn ships worth those 20,000, or more -using the entire match's unit value- and you will have second pick to the spawn table and it's very likely you'll be stuck with one unit facing an entire enemy fleet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, I decided I should re-Review this game by now.

This game, is a physics based Block building game, But No, this is -not- a minecraft clone, You are building war vessels, and structures, to fight the enemy forces of various sides, to try to control the planet.

That is a simple way to put the campaign mode, the physics do their job, but I am looking forward to the Unity 5 Update so it will help make it run even smoother in large battles.

Ground vehicles are 'slightly' in, There are wheels but not fully in yet.

This game does require some brainpower though to make effective creations, or things that will fly or sail at a good speed, with how the physics work, Though the only problem I see is missiles like to 'fall out of the air' when out of fuel, rather then glide along, But this is I believe going to be fixed when they work on missiles more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL:DR
This is a VERY nice game, I highly suggest putting atleast 5 hours or so into it to get to know the mechanics.

I do not even know where to start, this game is so huge, so I will start with how amazing the customization system is.
In other games, you might have a cannon, and it does a fixed amount of damage and has a fixed range, on here, guns are made from placing several diffrent blocks to determine it's stats. Is the gun a small machine gun that fires fast? Is the gun a massive ship cannon that fires a massive shell that explodes? Or maybe it fires AP rounds?
The list goes on.

The same goes with engines, is it a small, fuel conservative engine? Or maybe it guzzles fuel but has massive power?

Oh, and do not even get me started with the laser and jet engine customization. Oh, did I mention you can customize your AI?

The game also simulates ship armor. Maybe your armor is really thick but unsloped. Maybe you have lighter armor that slopes to bounce lighter shells?


The game is amazing, there is no way I could ever explain this entire game.

Overall, the pros and cons are:

Pros:

- high amounts of customization
- powerful ship editor
- planes, boats, subs, spacecraft, and soon to be ground forces.
- basic multiplayer

Cons:
- complex mechanics, but easy to learn.

First of all, please note that this game is in pre-alpha development. A lot of the main features are still under heavy development, and changing a lot. Only buy this game at this stage if it's something you don't mind.

Why do I rate it then? Because it was well worth my 20 euro's dispite the alpha status. All of my clocked time I was enjoying the game, dispite visible alpha status here and there.

Thanks to that I've gotten involved in the community, where the dev actually listens to the community, and responds to most sensible threads. Another great thing about the current development cycle is that players are involved in shaping and filling out the NPC factions. Not lazy design, but a great feature! Build something awesome and mean, and it might make it into the enemies.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of a kind! 9/10

Yes the learning curve is HUGE. I mean huge. You need patience for this game, but once you get going it is incredibly fun and addicting. The building is complex, but that makes it all the better in battle.

Pros
- Epic battles
- Good upgrade system
- Very complex. yet still intuitive
- Coop
- PvP
- Tons of content
- Unlimited possibilities
- Decent graphics
- Developers seem on the ball


Cons
- The movement of your character is a little buggy, but workable.
- Overall polish (it is still open access thought)
- Not too much of a con, but I would like to see some more rounded pieces
- Multiplayer is awesome and has the potential to be great, but if you do not know someone, then you may have a difficult time finding a game
- A ranking system for PvP that is not too advanced, but very basic could seriously add some brownie points (once game is finished)
- Not too much on the explainations (you can get by, but it is nothing like a tutorial)
- The sound is ok and workable, but is dull sometimes and repetitive.
- No epic background music during battles.

If you like buiding games and/or may have some friends who would want to play with you, this game is great. Just give it a few hours if you do get it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What is it:

From The Depths (abbreviated FTD in the future) conceptually is fairly simple. Create your own vehicles and wage war against other player's and/or AI controlled opponents in either scenario play, sandbox or a 'Grand Campaign' setting.

This is where it gets interesting. Creating your vehicles isn't a monumental task by any means but it requires a deeper understanding of the mechanics than might be apparent at first glance. Engines are designed block by block and vary in power output and fuel usage. Weight of your vehicle plays a vital role as most engagments are sea/air based and you can't have a boat that bobs and weaves in the water, you'd never be able to hit anything!

Basic learning curve is right around 5 hours with no handholding by the game itself. there are some pretty basic tutorials to get you going but by this time you should be able to make a small raft and make it move about with some simple guns on it.

Novice learning begins about the 10 hour mark where you've probably completed your first custom cannon and missle arrays and can make a solid ship that doesn't flip over when making a hard turn in rough waves. From here its all about refinement. You won't know how good you are until you match up against some of the big AI ships in the game and even those can be dealt with in clever and inexpensive ways.

Multiplayer is foreign to me. I haven't spent any time there yet in my 20+ hours and don't anticipate to do so in the near future.

Singleplayer is a blast if yet unrefined. The planned updates are very promising and what the developer has already delivered on is well worth your $20 if you can stick with it, watch/read a couple of tutorials and enjoy figuring things out on your own. once your first completely AI driven ships moves to take out an enemy fleet and succeeds, you'll be hooked.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI am not going to have this review be anything more than a review of the features I have experienced, namely the construction mode, piloting a boat and the controls in general. I'm going to start with the construction mode which I feel is the strongest part of the game. In the construction mode the controls are great, they work very well once you learn them which was annoying at start but once I learned what I was doing it got less irritating. There's a huge learning curve involved in this game but numerous online videos and ingame turtorials assist in this matter. My only real grievance with the construction mode is that forward, left, right and backwards are all relevant to the camera instead of being fixed. I personally do not consider this a weak point of the game mearly a different feature that appeals to different people depending upon who you are. The only final issue I have with the building mode is how you can'thave blocks levitate in mid air which I would have found very useful at it'd let me place down borders" for my vehicle. One other issue I have with the game is the inability to move blocks around after you place them down or select more than one block at a time. To sum this pargraph up the building mod is good and has a very strong series of core mechanics
date: if with a difficult and often annoying learning curve as well as a few control issues and lack of helpful features here and there.\n\nThe controls are great for piloting boats
recommended: not sure if they work for aeroplanes or the other vehicles as my personal lack of enjoyment with the game drove me off it before I got to that point
hoursPlayed: but when it comes to using turrets on rotating bases I found the only way I could decently aim was to stand on them which resulted in the turret being shot at an me getting knocked off
voteText: all the while I was being shot at. Personally I believe just removing the robot you played as would be easier for the game. When you're in the building mode this removal of the robot figure would simply place you as a disembodied camera. And when controlling vehciles being a disembodied camera wouldn't be useful I admit but a feature that "locks" you to the vehicle looking over it in a third person angle would be much easier. The final point I have to make regarding vehicle controls relates to the weapons and how they are only controlled if you're close to them
helpfulPercent: at least that was how the means of controlling them seemed. This system of only being able to control vehicles you're robot is standing on or close to sounds a little silly to me
votesHelpful:
after all you could easily get seperated from your vehicle due to incoming attacks.

Over all I give From the Depths a personal 6/10 and I would recomended it if games of this nature are your cup of tea.

+Creative and interesting concept.
+Good mechanics are sound
+Entertaining creating/building system

-Intimidating learning curve
-Feels unpolished in some areas
-Weapons can be difficult to use."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Think of the movie Waterworld. But will rivalizing factions.

Then you think about minecraft.. with a better interface, on steroids, with mirrorline when building in symmetry and auto-filling..

Then you want to place a gun on your new small ship.  Just put it down on a turret?  Nope !

First you put down the firing piece,  then you connect some 6-way connectors on the side of it, THEN you put some autoloaders, then you connect ammo-boxes to the autoloaders.   THEN you can add some explosive ammo boxes.. Oh it shoots to slow,  more autoloaders...     20 minuters later you notice your small ship starting to bank really horribly cause that 20 tonne gun on its side..

Why did my gun stop shooting all of a sudden?    Man i got no ammo. Gotto make some ammo barrels for big storing and ammo producers to keep them filled up.

Now i havent started on how to make a engine...

This is the most fun game i have played in a loooong time.  Also comes with a great community with lots of friendly helping on the forums and videoguides.

A clear 5 out of 5.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From The Depths is, quite simply, the best block-building game I have ever encountered. There are so many ways of playing the game that trying to nail down exactly it is that I love so much about it--there's just too much there to love! Vehicles are completely player-constructed and can be customized to a ridiculous extent, yet the basics of the game are simple enough that I was able to build a combat-worthy sea vessel within an hour or two of picking the game up. The graphics, while not fantastic, are serviceable, and the effects (especially explosions!) are satisfying.

The developer, Nick Smart, is responsive to the community, releases patches frequently, and constantly communicates with the community about his plans, asks for feedback on proposed ideas, and takes community suggestions seriously. This is early access done right.

The only downside that I can find to From the Depths is some of the textures are subpar, and that it keeps sucking up all my free time...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am enjoying the game very much. The freedom to build and fight your own vehicles is amazing, and it works beautifully for an Alpha game. I do have some suggestions though:

1) In creative mode, WSAD should always control horizontal plane and ♥♥♥♥ and space the vertical plane regardless of which way you are facing. The current method is unweildy.

2) Please, please, please: Instead of having our characters be miniature helicopters that slide and bounce around, just give us humanoid avatars subject to gravity so we can walk around.

3) Enemies should preferably be fastened to the deck for the most part. Hovering character melee/close quarters firearm combat is not fun.

Obviously this is an alpha and glitches and mechanics problems are to be expected, but these are my biggest gripes. Overall, great game! I highly reccommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ladies and Gentlemen!

I've played a lot of foraging/building/mining/crafting games.  I spent hours in Minecraft, Starbound, 7 Days to Die, DayZ, etc., etc., nothing eats up more of my time though than this game.  Ever dreamed of building YOUR personal aircraft carrier - what if you could then automate it and have it deploy several fighters to keep off enemy bombers.  Feel like you're in trouble from a submarine lurking below you..? Well, add some depth charges with a proximity fuse and carpet bomb the sea bed.  Anything you dream you can build in this game - and with the work the developer is putting in you can expect a lot of amazing features being added and graphics being tightened up.  The campaign is addictive and the vehicle designer allows you to submit your vehicle blueprints directly to the steam workshop!  This game is an absolute fungasm.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has shown me that indie games can be absolutely awesome.

Maybe I'm just a fast learner, but after a bit of messing about I'm already making great things. And I'm still just messing about in the designer, building stuff without constraints and such. Which is beyond fun by the way.

And you see all those ridiculously fancy pants thingos in the screenshots? I just want you to know that while all these things are huge complex things which probably took whoever made em days on end painstakingly working everything out to the very last block, they're things you and I can make too. I get the odd sensation when I'm playing From the Depths that, yes, anything is possible.

Unlike Minecraft, you've got way, way, waaaay more block shapes to choose from. There COULD be a few more shapes, but I'd say that'd just be going overboard, as it is I'm perfectly happy with it. I can make good looking boats, planes, helicopters, anything with what I've been given. In addition, you've got blocks that MOVE. As in, you point your mouse, a tiny spin block points to where your mouse is pointing.

Unlike Garry's Mod, you have far more freedom with your weapons and materials. You don't have to hunt through the prop list to find exactly what you need, no, it's always right there in front of you, ready to be grabbed. And it's actually fun killing stuff. Obviously less physics based than Gmod, but, well, you're never really going to want to pull out a catapult to fight a boat when you could fire a cannon instead. Or a laser. Or a missile. It's fun killing stuff.

And unlike Robocraft, this game is not actually ♥♥♥♥. It's satisfying to kill things. When things lose blocks, they get blown off and float around for a while before disappearing. When you hit something with a really really big cannon, and it does a lot of damage, it really feels like it. There's no stupid block limits or anything. Unless you build something outside of the designer, which I have not done, since the designer gives me all I need: materials, and infinite space.

Seriously, I know this looks like just another block-based building game, but it's the one that I've been waiting for (metaphorically). I wasn't expecting this even to be good. But it is. Just testing out my designs against enemy ships and planes is beyond exhilarating.

If you've got $20 to spend, pick this game up. It's eyebrow-raisingly expensive for an indie game, but I'm saying it's well worth it at present.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ever had that itch for something more than just minecraft? Something where the stuff you build is pitted against one-another while retaining that blocky, friendly atmosphere that you've grown accustomed to?

This is it.

Think of the most outrageous and OP vehicle ever in your head, whether it be a spaceship, aircraft, structure, land vehicle, or ship. This game can bring that thought to life. Why build huge airships in minecraft that can't really fly when in FtD they CAN fly, they CAN shoot, they CAN (and probably will) lead to hours upon hours of your life wasted away just to build, tweak, and perfect that one airship?
And for 20 bucks this indie game has drawn more fun from me than many AAA titles I’ve played (other platforms/computers). Not only that, but a community friendly to new and experienced players alike, a developer who actually cares about his playerbase and is SUPER active on the game forums, and full workshop, custom campaign, and soon to be modding support!  Another thing, if you look at the reviews 90% of those who gave this game a thumbs down have less then 20hrs put into this. My point? It takes time to learn.

Pros:
-awsome community
-LOTS of content
-active dev(s)
-workshop, custom campaign, and (soon to be) modding support
-easy to waste hours upon hours of time on

Cons:
-optimization is spotty, leading to needing a pretty beefy computer to be able to spawn in just one replica battleship
-multiplayer needs to be reworked
-I don’t have enough time each day to play this enough
Wanna know something though? Nick (the main/lead dev) has stated that he’s working to fix and improve all of these things and more!




Tl;dr	If you skipped to this before reading the rest of the review, then you don’t have enough patience for this game. End of story.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

40 Hours into the game and Im already building ships that can kill multiple bulwarks by itself. When everyone else struggles to even set up a cannon.

In all seriousness. Its a great game. It runs well with ordinary computers. Building is fun but time consuming. Most of my builds take a few hours or more to complete. My HoverCraft the Auxius has had around 5 hours of work put into it. And it still needs improvement. There are unlimited ways to make your vehicle. As there is LUA terminals for scripting (If you know how). And multiple vehicle types. Aircraft, Submarines, Helicopters, Battleships, Space craft, You name it. You can do it (Except for land vehicles). Everything you have to build from scratch. AI, Guns, Engine, ect. This is what I find the funnest thing about FTD. Being able to design the guns the way YOU want them. If you want them to shoot incredibly fast. You can do that. If you want to make one that shoots shells that could obliterate an entire ship in just a few shots, you can do that. But physics still apply. A large gun on a small hull can and will make your ship top heavy. That with the dynamic wave system. Can really 'rock' your ship. Campaign is fun. But hard at first. So I reccomend playing around in the creative session of the game and grab the ropes. Farther in the campaign you begin to come across hard battles. The ships you nerf because you think they are too overpowered will get killed pretty quickly. The Onyx Watch is such. They use no shields. But their ships are heavily armed and bulky. Meaning they can eat damage and deal even more back.

Oh. Also, watch out for the flying squirrels. They can eradicate your most armored ship easily.

Either way. This game is very addictive once you learn how to play. I rate this a 9.5/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From the Depths is the elephant you're going to want to eat with a fork.
I'm going to be blunt:  I like this game
On the surface it looks like just another block building game that you can manuever the vehicles.  But under the natural and approachable way the keyboard building mode works, you'll build ships of any and all possible configuration, you will arm these ships, with sensor arrays, lasers, defense lasers, long range missles.  tactical warheads, harpoons, torpedoes, torpedoes that launch into the atmosphere to splash into the ocean miles away to start hunting enemy ships, that you can't see.  -  That's just boats -  I spend six hours last night, messing around with the different size rockets that I can make to see what a certain combination of things would do...

I have 49 Hours of Game time, and I'm just barely scratching the surface.
Then you have Subs - Flying Boats - Planes - Planes that can launch from water - Blimps - Planes that can be blimps - Aircraft carriers that can fly and launch their own AI controled planes..... and helocopters.

Weapons platforms - Refuling stations - long range sensors - ICBM's.
How about that you also have above all this, a starship orbiting?  Yeah, you built that too.  Installed mainframe AI's.

And after you do all that fun, you go to war, where you command from a centralized command station, from any of your assets you have built, on a planet you designed, maybe with races you designed.....

For $20 bucks.

Yeah, I like this game.

and it works.
and it's ALPHA.
and the Dev is very involved.

Yeah, I like this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I definetly recommend this game, it's developers are active and good to the community, the game itself has a lot to it, 8 factions who all are memorable, especially Deep Water Guard and Onyx Watch (from my experience). The main concept of this game is that you are a little cute robot, all by yourself, and you have to make and build ships and destroy the 8 factions. The story itself is pretty vauge, but the lore is very nice and detailed (except for Steel Strider's lore, they are just the government, Barack Obama probably leads them.) By default you start out against the Deep Water Guard, pirates who want to kill you and pillage the little resources you have at the start, they are typically the longest faction to defeat, as they attack you when you are building up your forces, and they have a nice mix of every ship, and some fleets they build are devestating, a Moray, Barracuda, and Plunderer in a fleet together is almost complete death.


Pros:

Good developers
Incredible Replayability
Rarely Lags
You really use your imaginiation
You can build pretty much anything, from submarines to huge airships
There is multiplayer, but it isn't incredible at the moment
Steam Workshop integration
Lore is incredible
Community is incredible
Many more that I can't think of right now

Cons:

Tends to crash a lot
Doesn't autosave (yet)
It's quite complex and difficult to learn
A lot of Trail and Error, especially with air vehicles
Some more that I can't think of right now

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFrom the Depths is a really good early access game. Despite taking a long time to learn even the basics, if you watch a youtube series or two, read guides and put time into the game, you will learn it. When you finally unlock the campaign (since you have to reach level 4 to play it) and beat your first wave of DWG cannon fodder, you feel really good and satisfied. Everything must be built from scratch, whether by you or one of the built in prefabs. Building your first ship, your OWN ship (thats good) could take you a while to make, but using your creation to beat enemies is an experience like no other. One defeat in the early campaign can be devestating, and seeing a ship that got you so far reduced to nothing is actually sad sometimes, but that is part of the wonderful experience in the game. Oh, and I highly recommend Aavak, Enter Elysium and Lathland's From the Depths series'. I fully recommend this game.

Even being in early developent this is an excellent game, full of explosions, shooting and destruction. The learning curve can be a little steep at first but with plenty of tutorials and friendly forums that is not the issue it might seem at first.

The potential it shows is phenominal, and I have every belief that it will deliver on that promise, the dev's having sought and responded to feedback from the community at every step. Building custom weapons and AIs is easy and yet surprisngly versatile, and show's signs that it will only get better in time.

If you like MineCraft and explosions then this is for you!

Editted 2016: Everything I said up there? Still true and more so. The learning curve has been mostly tamed by in-game tutorials, that potential is being realised at every step. Very, very recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is absolutely brilliant in so many ways! I can remember way back when I was just a little kid playing G.I.-JOE's in the backyard. I didn't need the expensive, very cool toys that all of my friends had. Although the aircraft carrier was totally awesome, and the F-14 Tomcat was just bad a$$. I was perfectly fine using my mom's tupperware and various other types of household odds and ends to wage war behind the garage... All I needed was the little, flexible JOE's with cool nick-names. My imagination would take care of the rest!

Years later I am 36 years old, work my a$$ off and find it very hard or difficult to lose myself in my imagination just as I did many years ago! That is why I love video games. They give me the opportunity to leave my job behind me, venture off to uncharted territories and save the world from a vile, discusting and viscious evil with capabilities far beyond our very own. From the Depths not only allows me to venture off into La La Land, but I get to create the vessil of which I use to get there! Should I fly, or should I sail? Should I use a submarine or should I use an extremely huge aircraft carrier? These are a couple of the thousands of questions that From the Depths lets me ask. Just as I did years ago with my moms tupperware, I can create virtually any type of vehicle that I want to create... I am being serious... What ever it is that you can dream up, From the Depths allows you to build it. I do have to say that building your dream machine is not a walk in the park... At least not on the beginning. When you first turn it on the game does seem very overwhelming... EXTREMELY OVERWHELMING!!! As long as you do not let the complexity of this little gem detour you from having fun you will gradually get the hang of it amd before you know it you are building your very own Battleship with a vast array of turrets, missle silos, gun bunkers, engine bays, controll rooms and anything else that you might find on a Battleship. Along with other goodies that you would only find in... Your Imagination!!! After you have created a fleet of multiple armed and dangerous multi-terratoried vehicles you may sick your vast army on your friend, or foes vast army. Simply put... This game is a build it yourself version of the game Battleship, Legos, and Minecraft all rolled into one.

Although I highly recomend this game and that I truly believe that this game offers custimizable options unlike I have seen in any other game. Please note that it is complicated. It is not a game that you can just walk right in to. I have played it for only thirteen hours and I am still having trouble with it. But for me, the Juice is worth the Squeeze"! Although it is complicated I am quickly getting the hang of it and having a blast while learning to do so... A BLAST! I just finished building a boat that I have been wanting ti build since I was in the 8th grade. I still have a hard time believing that something I sketched out nearly 23 years ago is right here in front of me plowing along as fast as a speed boat while I am blasting a set of guns that I custom designed myself. Oh I forgot to mention... You can also design your very own weapons which you can put on your custom designed vehicles.

In conclusion I would like to say that if you are into building vehicles/forts/weapons
date: have a wild imagination and a srtong will to learn than this game is definately right up your alley. Everything you could ever want to build anything you want is right there in front of you on your screen. The learning curve is high as the Dev (there is only one... and he is great) has made ther game very easy to pick up as long as you have patience. Please do not let this game pass you up. It is a gem... A diamond in the rough that is still in it it's early stages (which is VERY hard to believe as good as the game runs) but is not far from being polished and placed on display!!!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(This is an overhauled review, but my opinion about this game is unchanged in the least bit. If you love to build, get it.)

I've been playing From the Depths for a very long time, and actually, I now assist with some of the game-building mechanics for one of the factions. For the sake of keeping things simple, I'll post below the positives and (few) negatives.

Pros:
- One of the most diverse building games out there. Seriously, there is very little that can even compare to From the Depths. You can build anything from a 30 block ballooncraft to 120000 block behemoths. (I don't advise trying to build something 120k blocks though. lol)
- Customization is now part of the game in that you can create your own campaign with your own designs, or simply just modify the current campaign. This adds to the diversity of the game.
- Graphically, it's not a bad game in the least bit, especially with high graphics.
- Overall, there are not many bugs in the game due to members testing the game in a development branch, where most issues are resolved before stable patches are released.
- The main developer is very active and responsive to community members. A lot of upcoming changes are actually due to members of the forums requesting them.

Cons:
- Right now, the game is very CPU intensive due to the current way the game calculates the physics, resulting in FPS dropping on most computers. This is due to Unity's standard raycasting being rather poor in calculations for large-scale battles, but work is being done to change these calculations to improve gameplay immensely.
- The learning curve for this game is quite steep at first. A lot of things won't make sense, but then again, with time, this is overcome. If you ever have trouble, just consult the forums and we'd be happy to help!

...that's about it for cons. If you love building and enjoying things explode, then what are you waiting for? Buy this game, enjoy it as your dream creations come to life!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a VERY interesting game, and I don't really regret the purchase in any way shape or form.
From The Depths may be discouraging at first from how complex it can be, and the learning curve can be moderately steep sometimes as you figure out some of the core mechanics, but in the long run, This is an excellent game.
When you learn a new method, and master the design you're striving to create, it's a rewarding experience.

Are you building a fleet of super light, affordable, mass produced ships, or floating castles that bring cannons the size of subway trains to bear? Will this design philosophy stand up to the test of battle? Only time will tell.

Bugs pop up, and bugs quickly get fixed. Updates happen on a nearly weekly basis. Another thing about this game that I REALLY like is that the developer, Nick Smart, is really involved with the community on the forums. He's open the suggestion & constructive criticism, Which is the hallmark of a happy community & productive developer.

Cons:-REALY complex, while I can't name any specific features ATM I totally believe that atleast something is unnecessarily complex

-Big systems can be constantly changing (custom cannons becoming cram cannot for example) so it could end up being a large amount of work to keep up with updates

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Saw some interesting videos about the game and decided to give it a try.

The game strongly suggests that you complete a series of tutorials that are intended to teach you the various aspects of the game. This is smart, since it would be kind to call the building controls clumsy, and they have a steep learning curve to gain any level of control. This is not helped by the tutorials and tooltips insisting on telling you the default control mappings and not using any re-mappings you may have done.

I was a bit surprised at how fast the tutorial ramped up the difficulty, with a very early tutorial Muddy Waters" giving you a very short time to repair a ship hull and build an engine before enemy ships blow your ship apart. I'm sure this is a trivial task for someone who has played the game for months and is an old hand at using the clumsy building controls to make numerous ships
date:
but having only about 10 minutes to fight the controls to build anything is quite the challenge only a few tutorials in.

Just two examples of clumsly build controls:
1) Placing and motion are relative to the camera
recommended:
not an absolute coordinate system. So as you try and find a camera angle where you can see what you are doing in cramped locations your control direction keeps changing with respect to trying to place blocks on the ship.
2) The cursor keeps moving toward/away from the camera every time you place or remove a block (depending if you right or left click). So if I'm trying to place blocks horizontally I have to keep re-adjusting the place cursor back to the row I'm working on.

I'm sure with enough time I could get used to how it behaved
hoursPlayed: except for the fact that you do not get an opportunity and are thrown into the timed build mission long before you have a chance to get used to the controls. It is literally the second time you build anything
voteText: and the first time was a "place the block I tell you here" sandbox mission.\n\nThe alpha nature of the game is very evident in the help/tutorial sections: spelling errors
helpfulPercent: sentences that just sort of trail off and missing words are just some of the more obvious. I've also encountered strange graphical glitches like the water surface vanishing; sometimes it is there and looks nice and other times not.\n\nTL;DR The game shows some promise
votesHelpful: but give it a pass until it gets out of alpha unless you like torturing yourself.\n\n(edit for spelling - thanks jordank321)"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is definitely a try it before you buy it kind of game.

The game engine is based on an old version of unity that can only use 1 core of your computer for simulating all of the blocks of the ships in a battle, so huge ships or large scale battles are out of the question. Gameplay balance is debatable, with single player being neglected for the sake of multiplayer tournaments, and an open multiplayer game is often impossible to find. Most people spend 100 hours learning to play before they really start enjoying themselves.

The online community is somewhat toxic, especially the developers. I was excluded from contributing content into the game by a kotl and the pr manager. I have been singled out as the target of jokes on the forum and teamspeak. I was outed as transgender against my wishes. I had people make an uncomfortable issue of my gender on teamspeak when I really did not want to discuss it. When I won a tournament I was insulted by the 2nd place finisher. I am the only player ever to receive a permanent ban. I was never given a temporary ban or a warning before this, I had a +21 positive rating on my profile when I was banned, and when I asked what recent behavior I was being punished for the dev said for equality". I responded that wouldn't be equality that would be corruption and spite and was banned permanently.

The game is boring without a community to interact with
date:
but if you have thick skin you might like it.

http://puu.sh/ozlGG/210d2570b8.jpg
http://fromthedepthsgame.com/forum/showthread.php?tid=5636&pid=51784#pid51784

~Miss Ion~"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While I'm usually not one for giving up on a game, this one deserved that honor in every regard. A game, which on the surface, looks interesting, unique and frankly deep in its options for creating voxel vehicles fall short a minute into its introduction.

Yet the entirely disgusting menu appearance, along with the tutorial that barely explains any of the concepts or mechanics of the game, to then ask you to go through and look at youtube video's to get a hold of the game. (Note to developer: Play Factorio, that game is quite a lot more advanced than this but it was able to make a tutorials that are engaging, challenging without the actual need of cups of frustration.)

I'm not even mentioning the awkward controls, the absolute ♥♥♥♥ building functions, the wobbling and confusing UI, disgustingly ugly textures along with other horrible design choices that makes this extremely hostile towards new players.

Do you want to relax and build? Don't buy this game.

Once more, when you want your players to watch youtube video's to get to know the basics of the game such as firing the weapons on a ship, you've done ♥♥♥♥ed up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To be honest, I love this game but can't in good conscience recommend it right now.  Yes, it's early access.  Yes, I know the game will change.  Yes, I know that make tutorials hard.  None of that softens my stance that this isn't worth the time it takes to find out how to play.  Not learn how to play because there's nothing in the game that is useful in *telling* you what to do.  Throwing together a hull and propellers isn't hard, but once you get into building engines or weapons the built-in guides are so scanty that they are very little use.  Especially since some parts only connect in certain ways and there is no easy way to see what is connected without tracing the entire path.  And you need those long paths since the guide examples with one (or a few) of each part are useless in the real game.    Don't get me wrong, the guides are good.  It's the game that doesn't give me the info I want in a useful way.  There's no way to know the number of parts I need without building them.  I *think* it's the ratio between parts that's important, but there's no way to verify that.

There are ways to find out what to do, but Look for people playing the game on YouTube" is not a substitute for in game info.  Let's say you want your base to have a horizontally-rotating turret with a single gun in it to shoot aircraft; that sounds pretty cool!  *Open build menu* Hmm no turret listed.  Let's try custom cannons.  Nope.  Advanced cannons?  Also nope.  Misc tab? Nope^3.  As a noob you didn't go to  'New Object'->'Two axis turret'->'One Axis Turret'.  But let's say we found that and started construction.  We slap down the main piece and hook up the ammo boxes and other blocks to give us the explodey
date: armor piercing goodness that we want.  How much of each does your gun need?  Beats me.  Just slap things on&off and figure it out.  Finally
recommended: we need our gun to elevate to attack flyers.  Oh look
hoursPlayed: a block called Elevation Barrel!  How many do I need to hit 60-70 degrees?  Beats me.  You have to slap them on and then either scroll your way back to the firing piece block or just try out the gun to see if you put in enough.\n\nFiguring out how to play the game should be a choice of tradeoffs.  I should be asking myself "Is it worth the resources to have guns that elevates to 80 degrees or is 60 enough?"
voteText: and not asking "How in the gently caress do I get a rapid firing gun that elevates to 60 degrees with alternating explosive and armor piercing shots!?"  The entirety of my issues with the game could be solved with a 'design wizard' that would let me see how the number of parts affects the final stats.  I'm fine with something that let's me see that I need x gauge increasers
helpfulPercent: y cooldown decreasers
votesHelpful: and z recoil dampers.  I'll take it from there and work on fitting them in.  Without something like this
votesTotal:
I find that I need to regularly stop playing the campaign mode and go into the designer to get a weapon I want.  I would much rather prefer trying to fit in the parts I know I need under the time pressure of an approaching enemy.

Full disclosure:  I have still haven't gotten belt-fed autoloaders to connect properly(They work now!  Details below).

Gun stats provided in game: -Max shell diameter: 0.020 -Gun has 1m ammo clip and loader
Ammo stats: -Shell diameter: 0.018 -Clip size required: 1m
Error message that gun cannot be loaded.

Can you guess what the problem is?  If you guessed that the shell was too big to fit in the gun
votesFunny: you're right! (although it beats me how I should have known that)  I reduced the number of shell parts and now it all both fits and tears up the Onyx Watch flyers.\n\nIf this was helpful
commentsCount: please stay tuned.  I'll happily update the review if things improve."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Huh.  I read a lot of the reviews and they are universally positive.  After seeing the screenshots, the game looks quite interesting.  The UI looks clunky, and the graphics aren't that good, but I was willing to give it a shot.

And I gotta tell you, this game lost me pretty quick.

The UI is worse than clunky: It is downright incomprehensible at times, and is a serious of confusing beveled rectangles that are sometimes buttons, sometimes radio controls and other times just static text.

I had to alt-tab out of the game and look up hints on the forum on what to do or how to manipulate the UI, and these hints were sometimes very vague.  The graphics are jarring and mismatched, as if six different styles of art were crammed together.  (Or six different artists worked on the game.)  The audio is not very good, with the same 30 second sea sound effect looped over and over.  The build mode is clunky and difficult to figure out;  Creating just a simple craft required several hours of tweaking and messing about.

The missions are many and varied, but at times it's impossible to figure out what you are supposed to be doing due to the minimal mission-objective UI.  Building the right sort of craft to complete each mission takes a while (due to aforementioned tweaking) and I lost patience trying to win each scenerio.

The controls are atrocious.  It uses a lot of none-standard, none-intuitative key binds for critical functions, and it's difficult to play the game on a laptop because of this.

There's a lot of depth to this game (ha!), considering how many building parts there and how they can be linked together to make all kinds of vehicles, but it's really just not very playable or enjoyable game to me.   Which is weird, because I read the reviews and people are absolutely raving about this game.  But to me. From the Depths feels like a very early prototype game, a proof-of-concept that needs a LOT of shine and polish before I would have considered it a public alpha.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThere is currently no fun aspects to this game unless you find 3+ hours of tutorials and having to use imagination to make your own story fun. It's basically figure it out simulator and I no longer have the patience to try to figure it out myself. If a game uses 30% of an 8 core processor at the start menu... you know you're in for a bad time...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

!WARNING!

This is a long review. The short version is this : The physics aren't right to the point where the AI is the only reliable pilot. Unless the physics are fixed, the game will be unplayable for me. I don't find it fun to design an amazing ship only to watch an AI have fun with it. Unless you are prepared to spend long hours trying to learn the mechanics of this game and brave the incredibly steep learning curve, I would recommend you waiting until the game is developed further. It has great potential, but very serious issues holding it back from being great.

1. Physics
A: Boats
B: Planes
2. Tutorials and learning
3. User Interface.
4. Controls

( Note that the other categories I can't cover due to character limits. So what if my review is 17,138 characters long? That's how many characters I need to sum up the experience! So I'll just cover the main issue. )

I've sunk a few hours into this game and I liked the concept. But I didn't realize what that concept really was. I came into this game expecting something like Starmade but with planes and boats. What I got was something very different.


1. Physics

The main issue I have with this game is the physics. They just aren't right at all. The objects don't behave the way you would expect them to and the forces that act on objects don't seem right at all. Thrust of any kind on even a very heavy object don't seem proportionate. I will try to explain.

A: I first tried to make a boat. After long hours of fruitless experimentation, I found out that boats do not take into account account the amount of air inside of an enclosed space. I experimented on this concept and found that I could have two objects of the same weight but different volumes of air and they floated identically. So this tells me that the volume of air is not being calculated. The weight of the object seemed to be the only factor determining it's buoyancy. Both of these objects had air pumps, I should mention.

Initially when I was making my first ship, I thought that it would be best if I start small and aim for a ship that could move quickly. The issue with making these small boats was: Whenever I would put a significant amount of thrust to the back side of the boat, the nose would rise up out of the water almost immediately and the boat would backflip in the air and land upside down in the water. So of course I tried moving the rotors to the front of the ship only to have the same issue. I got very frustrated and added immense amounts of lead blocks to the nose of the vessel and even with more weight than the entire hull of the ship, the nose would rise up out of the water and the boat would capsize.

Naturally I gave up on the idea of a fast boat as it was clearly impossible for me. So I moved on to making a sturdy boat that might be able to withstand some punishment as I couldn't seem to move very quickly without capsizing. After a long time I made something that was barely buoyant but I was able to reach about 20 – 24 meters per second without the ship flipping. Even this was only possible with very close attention placed on the 'water drive'. If I pushed it to the maximum, even that would flip it. So I was able to get a ship that weighed 1251.51 go at about 20 - 24 meters per second, which was the fastest I had gone in the water without the ship flipping, but I could not get a ship that weighed 118.75 to go any faster than roughly 6 – 10 meters per second. And even at that speed it would flip.

Even with this small victory, there were yet more problems. Now the issue was that I would roll over completely if I wanted to make an even relatively sharp turn. Your ship does not right itself well. Period. It does not act it's weight. What I mean by this is that everything is very 'floaty'. If for example my nose would climb out of the water and I would end up perpendicular to the water ( my ship's nose pointing directly up into the sky ) the ship's nose would fall back into the water at the same speed as the much smaller 118.75 weight ship. As for the rolling of the ship, the same thing is true. Now, if you want to use a cannon, oh boy, you had better hope you're not shooting broadside because if you do, you're rolling! The strange thing that I noticed is that you could be stock still in the water and if you try to turn, nothing happens. This makes sense as the rudder is the only thing turning you, assuming you don't have rotors on either side of the nose of your ship to try to turn you. ( Even those don't seem very effective in my experience.) Now if you get any kind of speed, your ship will start to roll if you try to turn it. It's not as though it's rolling from the force of your speed as it seems to start rolling at 1 meter per second. So you're moving it 1 meter per second and you can completely roll your ship belly up in the water. This does not work in reality. I have been on big ships. It doesn't happen. So it seems like instead of having true ship physics, it feels copy pasted from the plane physics. It's rolling the ship like a plane would with ailerons. So sharp turns in ships would only be possible if you were to use the rolling to your advantage and then attach rotors to the underside of the nose of the ship and the use that to turn yourself, again, like a plane might. But that's not feasible as your nose is likely to be out of the water, and if it isn't already, those rotors on the underside will solve that quite quickly.


B: The next thing were the planes. I struggled immensely with planes. It was nigh on impossible for me to get anything to fly that didn't  act as if it had twenty anvils attached to the tail. Every time I built a plane, it would pull up constantly. It was as though the joystick of the plane was pulled back at all times. I would have to try to push the nose of the plane down constantly just to stay level. It was infuriating. I eventually found something after hours of testing that would sort of work. It was a flat block shaped like a T with wings at the upper ends of the T. The weight almost didn't seem to matter as far as the constant rising problem; As I could make the entire T shape out of heavy metal and it wouldn't make a difference. It would, however, cause the plane to fall more quickly but did nothing to affect it's orientation. As soon as I tried building the T thicker, it would go back to the constant rising.

So about the only thing I was able to make with any kind of success was a fortress. Yes, a massive floating piece of metal that barely moved.  With a gun.

Great concept, horrible execution, not much fun. The controls are horrible, your fighting the camera constantly, the building is tedious, and the controls for that are miserable as well. Just trying to figure out how to build a simple boat that works is a three hour long process. The scheme of the game is all over the place, steampunk, future robot, and post apocalyptic, all mixed together, but not in a good way, more in a different artists having very different ideas. The water is invisble untill your under it. Its just so many little things that make this one big giant crap fest.

The tutorials are also confusing, but they give you plenty to choose from. Read about how to, watch someone else do it, and play through it yourself. However, they aren't very clear, more of click on this to add this now add this, place some of these, and there you go your a good Stanley! After you do them, your like but wait, what did I just do exactly?

The controls, argggg the controls. There are some games where your pretty sure thats the difficulty is dealing with the terrible controls or fighting a terrible camera, well this gives you the power of both. Every time you place a block the screen kicks a block forward towards the cameras direction. Which can and will screw you over. Trying to change your creations is also a nightmare if you forgot to add a chair.

I know this is in EA so hopefully they will do something about the control scheme. Because you know half the point of this game is to build stuff to fight others with. So far building crap is so horrible and annoying that only the diehards are seriously building. And thats great, the world needs architects, I'm just not an engineer by trade and didn't read in the description that I should be.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is potentially a great game. The mechanics are wonderful. It runs very fast and smooth and i do love a good meta-strategic long-game.
HOWEVER. beginning the game even with assistance of an experienced player is a long, frustrating and unrewarding experience.
First you're going to have to get to grips with a very fast, hotkey based control system. -which is great - except you can't modify the keys to your liking so if you're intuitive and fast with another game or program you're going to have to UNLEARN all of that first.
Right now i can't stop hitting E because i use it to pitch in a couple of other games (those games allow me to tune the controls when a button clashes) but FTD forces me into a tactical map view about once a minute.
FOR THE LOVE OF BISCUITS WHY CANT I REMAP CONTROLS?
Also you are in two places. you have an avatar for some reason. No idea why since it's invincible, doesnt do the construction and has such bizarre movement characteristics that you never want to be first person viewing.
The second viewpoint is a sort of spectator-cam that moves at supersonic speed with a momentary blip on the directional key. -again adding to the feeling of being trapped in a clumsy, jerky body with no influence on surroundings.


OK, putting all this aside you set about trying to learn the ropes 'cause it looks like fun once you know them.
You have a few options:

Vehicle Designer - infinite resources, virtually nothing to restrain you or drive your build. What am i building for? oh, the campaign. but i have no idea what works in campain. 'cause i'm here trying to get ready for campaign. SO i place blocks for an hour or two, get bored with how awful they look and exit to main menu.

Campaign - i go to start campaign since many games use missions as a way to introduce game concepts - Offering microgoals to help the player understand mechanics and priorities - maybe this game will be like that. Nope. Just plopped on a raft in the middle of a hostile ocean with 5 factions at high development levels and minimal pointers on how to even begin to gather resources.


Multiplayer - obviously a place you go once the new player skill-cliff is a distant nightmare. I can't offer you any reports on this.

I'm glad i own this game because when it's done it could be wonderful but having to re-train my hands to use it simply because the devs won't let players remap controls spoils the experience enormously.

TLDR: Great potential. Maybe awesome if you've been playing since day one and all the complexity got added underneath you but it's becoming inaccessible to new players. Too little reward for your time.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game looks amazing, runs well, and has a great concept. Sadly, I am not a ♥♥♥♥ing genius. The game is extremely hard and the game mechanics are not explained. There are so many different settings and options and I do not know what they do or how to use them (such as difficulty. The difficulty option is garbage. Instead of easy, medium, and hard mode, it is 0.00-???.) I tried to play but the cannons would not work. I searched the boat for the computer thingy that I saw in a video. Apparently, this thing was very important and turned on the boats AI. I found it but turning on the AI did not make the ship fight back when enemies came by. I also played some other mode where I had to capture a ship but I was killed everytime I got close. I placed a cannon but it did not work so I could not defend myself. I tried to steer to the ship I had to take over but my boat flipped over. I assume that I need to place some sort of ammo container but I could not find one in the inventory. I also noticed that every single object says press Q when you get to it but pressing Q only controls the AI unless you press it on a door. This is garbage and I have requested a refund. Maybe I will buy it when there is more explanation and help added. I am VERY VERY disappointed. I was expecting a fun game about fighting ships and flying vehicles but I got a game harder to control than Kerbal Space Program (and that says ALOT about how difficult it is). I rate 1/10. reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you aren't understanding the tutorial 1hr in and aren't enjoying anything, refund it because it does not change at all. Best advice would be for a demo consisting solely of the tutorial and a free build mode to be released so that people can try before they buy. Game is overly complicated just for the sake of being so. The default controls make the dark souls mouse+keyboard controls look good, the tutorial makes you look at youtube videos to learn how to play rather than doing the job of a tutorial AND TEACHING YOU HOW TO PLAY. Seriously, kerbal space program is about sending stuff into space and does 1000x better at teaching the player how to play as well as makes it engaging, whereas this is a game about building things and making them fight other things and collecting resources. A game about rocket science is less complicated and more fun than a game about building stuff and blowing up other stuff.
Suggestions:
Make a proper tutorial that spends more time having you build things than it does giving you slideshows with bad camera angles and manual pages to read.
Put the fixed tutorial and a free build mode up as a demo so that people don’t waste time and money on something they don’t like.
Wouldn’t recommend this to anyone who likes building games unless they were looking for kerbal with added layers of complication and dark souls controls.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

3/10
I saw all the pretty little screenshots and thought wow this must be an amazing building/combat game!!!
BOY was i ♥♥♥♥ing wrong.
1: the learning curve on this is ASTOUNDING. There are extensive tutorials for this game, but the tutorials throw you right into a MASSIVE builder, which is literally EVERYTHING you can build. Seriously? you just expect to us to comprehend all of that info?
2: The combat is awesome... IF you or the other person knows what the hell they are doing. I see this game as a more advanced toribash.
3: The limited amount of experienced players are mostly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥S. I came across one guy who i had asked for help while we were battling. He taught me how to make a neat ship, it was a tiny little raft with one cannon. His ship literally steamrolled my ship. Did i mention how this game works? which finally brings me to my next point...
4: BIGGER = BETTER. If your ship is the size of a planet, chances are the other guy's game will crash or he will be destroyed by the shear massiveness of the ship. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great uninstall simulator. 10/10 Would uninstall again

The developers seriously need to address the insane learning curve that haunts this game. I understand that they are aware of this and are taking measures to combat the situation but more still needs to be done. The game seems like a complete cluster-f**k of huge buttons being thrown in your face right from the start. The UI is clunky and half of your screen is taken up by the GUI when in-game. Even with all of the helpful" tutorials that come with the game it is still hard to grasp the basics. I appreciate that it is in early access but it is still not worthy of the £14.99 price tag. I do enjoy complex games that take a while to master but "From The Depths" takes a while just to navigate the menu and controls. The game has a huge potential and i love the concept. Hence the reason that i decided to pick it up. I just hope that the developers can continue to improve their game. Overall i do not recommend the game at the moment and this negative review will remain until the developers do more to address the situation."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do not get this game until they fix the terrible building controls

Playing this game feels like a chore, that is, if you want to create things. The combat in the game is very fun, but that is where the potential of this game comes to an end. In order to create even the smallest of boats, one must spend upwards of an hour to make it work properly, and even then you end up with a peice of ♥♥♥♥ that can't compete with the workshop blueprints. I feel like this game is unplayable to anybody not willing to spend at least 4 hours learning the mechanics, which sounds easy and tolerable at first, but ends up being a drag. You will buy this game, start it up and then think that for some reason you can jump right on in, and that you don't need to watch the tediously long videos on how to change the direction of a wooden triangle. You will start to build a boat, then halfway through get frustrated and go back to watch the videos, you will then repeat this process around 4 times within the first hour of the game.

It is so frustrating that you start to get stressed, not a good stressed like facing a boss in dark souls, but the type you feel when you have an essay due in an hour and you haven't started it. I feel like the one and only reason this game is getting good reviews is that people don't want to admit that they can't build anything amazing so they act like the game is simple.

All in all, if you buy the game stick to using other peoples stuff and actually play the game, don't spend hours attempting to learn the building basics that are on par with the difficulty of the blender software.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The building in this game is good especially the keyboard controlls BUUUUT  the way you stear the vehicle is bad. Maybe if they attached the character to the wheel would be best and using the normal controls for steering. Instead you just have to be on the vehicle and it uses different keys on the keyboard. The game controls are so cluttered that any new person has to drown in video tutorials to understand how to do anything. Also the UI is crap and WAY overcomplicated. you can build your own engine and guns is really cool but the menues and UI tries throw so much information at you that it becomes too much. Final gripe here is the bots. In first person there is this limb clipping where if you turn the arm turns before the head and you can see detachment which is annoying. They also have poor models and textures. Finally their movements are too wild in and the ability to fly and survive under water ruins the feel of the game.

TLDR summery: controls are very bad, UI is very bad, player model is TERRIBLE, way too much learning and not enough playing, building is cool.

This game has SO much potential and perhaps by release it will be one of my favorites but until then I reccomend you skip over this one for now.

Obvious problem whit the game is its price, its too high for a indie game what is in alpha. It should be max 10 Euros, instead being almost 20.

I dont recomend to buy this game for this price, it dosent deserve to be more than 10€
