reviewText:
Early Access Review

For me, the quality and value of an Early Access game is represented primarily by two things: the state of the current build and the level of involvement of the dev(s) within the community. The latter I believe is the foundation of a healthy community for pretty much all indie games. ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off and unpassionate devs tend to result in a community with a black cloud lingering above it. I think these aspects are about 50/50% as far as importance to me, with either not being fulfilled to some degree usually being a dealbreaker for me. The software usually stands up to the test, but in cases where the devs are not involved with the community or updates come at barely a trickle or seem non-existant, I usually expect that there will be no or a poor community and and that can ultimately lead to an EA game which feels like it ever reaching beta, let alone a release build which the majority of players will be happy with, starts to become more and more of a longshot (i.e. Blockscape, Castle Story, Spacebase DF-9).

I've managed to sample every voxel sandbox game I can get my hands on and for a time now, my favorites have been Space Engineers and 7 Days To Die. They're both great games with great devs and communities. That was, until I found From The Depths. What is missing from Space Engineers (albeit is on the way), currently, are things to do WITH the ships and stations you've built (a campaign) and a block-based AI system and AI factions to assign ships to so you can fight, create fleets, etc. Well, those are the things this game has in spades. The AI isn't perfect yet, but I must say it was very impressive to see how diverse and powerful the options for configuring the AI actually are and just how very functional it is already. Other than an issue with aircraft occasionally colliding or hanging up wings with other craft in their own fleet, I haven't seen anything else wrong with the AI at all. The tools you need to build incredibly complex, functional, and automated vehicles are all there. You are limited only by the block count your PC can display and your own imagination.

The learning curve doesn't feel terribly steep either relative to the rather deep complexity provided by the sheer number of building options you have. The game has a very well-designed tutorial system accessible from right in the relevant block selection tabs. These tutorial vignettes show you a quick reference of how to block out each of a vehicle's subsystems, such as engines, aircraft, spin blocks and rotor blades (for helicopters), turrets, custom cannons and missles, etc., so you should rarely feel confused as to how to go about implementing each in your own designs. It's really very easy to pick up, hard to put back down, and difficult to master.

I also cannot speak highly enough about what I have seen from the game's creator Nick Smart either. Normally, I'd say that a game like this on Early Access is a gamble on what may be potential shovelware and probably not worth the risk except in rare cases, but I feel this game really is one of those rarities. I was really shocked by how communicative, helpful and just overall the presence he has on the official forums. After a cursory skim of the forums, I was genuinely convinced that he loves this game and it is apparent that it is so much more than just a job/paycheck to him. I would dare say that he *gasp* actually plays his own game. I have yet to come across a single instance in which he responded negatively to a request or inquiry. Surprisingly, he is very much a yes man who is at the same time capable of following through. If you have a good idea that is even mildly popular among the other forum members and it is possible to implement, it is probably going to actually end up in the game over the course of the next build or three. I simply can't assign enough value to that.

There are currently three game modes:

> Vehicle Designer - The creative mode of the game. This is where most people will probably spend the bulk of their time. You can use all blocks save the couple advanced ones which must be unlocked (see Story Mode below) and have unlimited resources at your disposal. Here you can save and load any designs you've built as well as any of the massive number of designs you can download off the Steam Workshop. There are also a nice selection of designs that are used by the campaign factions and you can load them up in here to play around with/reverse engineer them as well. Spectating or participating in AI battles is possible by loading the designs and assigning them to one of the enemy factions. Every design is contained in a data.txt file that you can easily share with others without using the Steam Workshop at all.

> Story Mode - Each of the enemy factions has it's own set of story missions which are unique scenarios in which you are given a task to complete (i.e. destroy a ship) and an RP (resource point) limit that you can spend to create the craft(s) to complete the task. There are currently 4 advanced block types to unlock by completing their respective missions, so new players will probably want to at least complete those 4 to unlock those blocks for use in the Campaign. Each mission has it's own default fleet, which you can (and should) customize to your liking, however, you can scrap the defaults altogether and use the RP to build a completely new design from scratch if you so choose. There are currently only a handful of Story Mode missions available, but the UI shows a lot of space for more beneath the existing ones, so I'm going to assume that many more are planned for the future. Though not very plentiful, these are highly replayable since there are just so many ways you could go about it.

> Campaign - In this mode, you start out with a single Skyfortress (a floating structure/base) parked over a lone Resource Zone and one of the several enemy factions is hostile towards you. Hitting the [M] key will delight you with a strategic map of the entire planet, which shows all the other Resource Zones, enemies' bases and fleet locations, as well as all of the planet's landmasses. You are not given any set goals or required to do anything, although the one faction who is hostile will start sending fleets your way in due time to try and wipe you out, so building a vehicle with weapons to defend yourself and/or outfitting your Skyfortress with some long range weapons would be wise. The other non-hostile factions will not try to attack you until provoked, so the safest (probably intended) method of progression is to whittle each faction down one at time until you control the entire map, but that is up to you, you could also declare war on all of them if you are fond of a difficult challenge and are not terribly frightened of watery graves.

To address the issue of performance being affected by how many blocks are in play at a given time, the game features a rather clever method of solving it. Each of your fleets can be in one of two states: either in play (visble and fully interactable) or pulled from play. When pulled, fleets are not rendered or affected by physics, but can still be moved using the strategic map, and in the case of skyfortresses, can still collect resources if parked in an RZ. Enemy fleets are always pulled from play until you engage them by moving one of your fleets into range (there's a large cyan ring around each fleet to indicate this range) or they move within range of one of your fleets on their own. If all fleets are pulled, you have available two additional timescale options from within the map: 4x and 10x. This addresses the issue of a very slow fleet needing to move great distances and it not really being too fun to sit and watch at 1x. The campaign has three different difficulty sliders, each of which affects either the enemies or economy so you can fine tune the campaign to be as easy or hard as you'd like.

Overall, I am blown away by just how addictive this game is.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From the depths is an AMAZING game considering its alpha state.

It has a construction engine similar to Space engineers, IE placing blocks of various materials to form a structure, objects such as generators and engines to give power to items such as propellers, jets, etc. (Though it has more useful features like mirror, fill, position and free flying around the vehicle)

Everything is very logical and fairly intrinsic, but moreso is that each section of your crafting menu with a complex object (IE an engine, gun, AI system) has a nice little tutorial that you can select and walk through section by section.

This game as an immensely complex crafting system, and the sheer number of options are daunting, but take your time just fussing around with things and checking the tutorial when you get confused, and it's pretty easy to learn and very fun to see what you can come up with. But even MORE fun to pit your creations against others.

Ultimately this game is extremely fun for a tinkerer such as myself, considering that I not only get to build all kinds of curious war machines, but you actually get to test them against enemies as well. There are even unlockable items via story (Challenge) missions, and a RTS-esque campaign of using your custom built army to dominate a map filled with several factions of varying allegiance and attitude towards the player.
On top of that your charater gains levels and has equipment and skills that can be unlocked, though currently some are not implemented entirely.


As it stands, this game is simply amazing with its current features, and quite fun. But the even moreso is the potential of the game.
Look up Budkai (1
hoursPlayed: etc)K tournament" on youtube for an awesome
voteText: action filled example of what the game has to offer. You should find several tournaments where player machines (Controlled by AI) fight to the death!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For me, the quality and value of an Early Access game is represented primarily by two things: the state of the current build and the level of involvement of the dev(s) within the community. The latter I believe is the foundation of a healthy community for pretty much all indie games. ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off and unpassionate devs tend to result in a community with a black cloud lingering above it. I think these aspects are about 50/50% as far as importance to me, with either not being fulfilled to some degree usually being a dealbreaker for me. The software usually stands up to the test, but in cases where the devs are not involved with the community or updates come at barely a trickle or seem non-existant, I usually expect that there will be no or a poor community and and that can ultimately lead to an EA game which feels like it ever reaching beta, let alone a release build which the majority of players will be happy with, starts to become more and more of a longshot (i.e. Blockscape, Castle Story, Spacebase DF-9).

I've managed to sample every voxel sandbox game I can get my hands on and for a time now, my favorites have been Space Engineers and 7 Days To Die. They're both great games with great devs and communities. That was, until I found From The Depths. What is missing from Space Engineers (albeit is on the way), currently, are things to do WITH the ships and stations you've built (a campaign) and a block-based AI system and AI factions to assign ships to so you can fight, create fleets, etc. Well, those are the things this game has in spades. The AI isn't perfect yet, but I must say it was very impressive to see how diverse and powerful the options for configuring the AI actually are and just how very functional it is already. Other than an issue with aircraft occasionally colliding or hanging up wings with other craft in their own fleet, I haven't seen anything else wrong with the AI at all. The tools you need to build incredibly complex, functional, and automated vehicles are all there. You are limited only by the block count your PC can display and your own imagination.

The learning curve doesn't feel terribly steep either relative to the rather deep complexity provided by the sheer number of building options you have. The game has a very well-designed tutorial system accessible from right in the relevant block selection tabs. These tutorial vignettes show you a quick reference of how to block out each of a vehicle's subsystems, such as engines, aircraft, spin blocks and rotor blades (for helicopters), turrets, custom cannons and missles, etc., so you should rarely feel confused as to how to go about implementing each in your own designs. It's really very easy to pick up, hard to put back down, and difficult to master.

I also cannot speak highly enough about what I have seen from the game's creator Nick Smart either. Normally, I'd say that a game like this on Early Access is a gamble on what may be potential shovelware and probably not worth the risk except in rare cases, but I feel this game really is one of those rarities. I was really shocked by how communicative, helpful and just overall the presence he has on the official forums. After a cursory skim of the forums, I was genuinely convinced that he loves this game and it is apparent that it is so much more than just a job/paycheck to him. I would dare say that he *gasp* actually plays his own game. I have yet to come across a single instance in which he responded negatively to a request or inquiry. Surprisingly, he is very much a yes man who is at the same time capable of following through. If you have a good idea that is even mildly popular among the other forum members and it is possible to implement, it is probably going to actually end up in the game over the course of the next build or three. I simply can't assign enough value to that.

There are currently three game modes:

> Vehicle Designer - The creative mode of the game. This is where most people will probably spend the bulk of their time. You can use all blocks save the couple advanced ones which must be unlocked (see Story Mode below) and have unlimited resources at your disposal. Here you can save and load any designs you've built as well as any of the massive number of designs you can download off the Steam Workshop. There are also a nice selection of designs that are used by the campaign factions and you can load them up in here to play around with/reverse engineer them as well. Spectating or participating in AI battles is possible by loading the designs and assigning them to one of the enemy factions. Every design is contained in a data.txt file that you can easily share with others without using the Steam Workshop at all.

> Story Mode - Each of the enemy factions has it's own set of story missions which are unique scenarios in which you are given a task to complete (i.e. destroy a ship) and an RP (resource point) limit that you can spend to create the craft(s) to complete the task. There are currently 4 advanced block types to unlock by completing their respective missions, so new players will probably want to at least complete those 4 to unlock those blocks for use in the Campaign. Each mission has it's own default fleet, which you can (and should) customize to your liking, however, you can scrap the defaults altogether and use the RP to build a completely new design from scratch if you so choose. There are currently only a handful of Story Mode missions available, but the UI shows a lot of space for more beneath the existing ones, so I'm going to assume that many more are planned for the future. Though not very plentiful, these are highly replayable since there are just so many ways you could go about it.

> Campaign - In this mode, you start out with a single Skyfortress (a floating structure/base) parked over a lone Resource Zone and one of the several enemy factions is hostile towards you. Hitting the [M] key will delight you with a strategic map of the entire planet, which shows all the other Resource Zones, enemies' bases and fleet locations, as well as all of the planet's landmasses. You are not given any set goals or required to do anything, although the one faction who is hostile will start sending fleets your way in due time to try and wipe you out, so building a vehicle with weapons to defend yourself and/or outfitting your Skyfortress with some long range weapons would be wise. The other non-hostile factions will not try to attack you until provoked, so the safest (probably intended) method of progression is to whittle each faction down one at time until you control the entire map, but that is up to you, you could also declare war on all of them if you are fond of a difficult challenge and are not terribly frightened of watery graves.

To address the issue of performance being affected by how many blocks are in play at a given time, the game features a rather clever method of solving it. Each of your fleets can be in one of two states: either in play (visble and fully interactable) or pulled from play. When pulled, fleets are not rendered or affected by physics, but can still be moved using the strategic map, and in the case of skyfortresses, can still collect resources if parked in an RZ. Enemy fleets are always pulled from play until you engage them by moving one of your fleets into range (there's a large cyan ring around each fleet to indicate this range) or they move within range of one of your fleets on their own. If all fleets are pulled, you have available two additional timescale options from within the map: 4x and 10x. This addresses the issue of a very slow fleet needing to move great distances and it not really being too fun to sit and watch at 1x. The campaign has three different difficulty sliders, each of which affects either the enemies or economy so you can fine tune the campaign to be as easy or hard as you'd like.

Overall, I am blown away by just how addictive this game is.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Thought it was just going to be another block builder set in a sea setting.

It's another block builder. With guns. Guns that you can build the barrels to affect firing characteristics. Or change the ammo characteristics. Lasers. Nasty deadly steampunk lasers that you set up laser networks to create the beam for the optics. Missiles... with modules... want a beamrider missile so you point where you want it to go? Sure. How about a heat seeker that seeks out the engine modules? Can do! Fire and forget? Don't forget the IFF module or nearby friendly ships might want to return the favor.

Can make submarines, ships, tanks, planes, airships, and spaceships!

This little game is a fantastic little gem.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very complete ship/plane/flying steampunk airship building and combat game. The building UI takes some time getting used to, but otherwise quite robust when you learn the keys. Its only real weakness are barebones single player missions, but they are playable and have great potential. The conquest mode on the other hand is very fun as you take resources and land from warring AI factions with your own custom designed air and sea force.

Compared to say space engineers, this game is much more combat focused. With mutiple weapon systems such as custom guns, Missiles and torpedos big and small, and laser weapons. Unlike space engineers almost every behavior from your craft's movement to its weapons behavior can be programed customly. You can make a craft the snipes at the enemy with cruise missiles, or charges in and smashes the enemy with huge cannon.

If spending hours building a flying Missile guided Dreadnought out of blocks sounds fun to you, this early access game is a good pick up. If you don't like building, you might not like this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTICE: This review was written during the alpha stage of the game.

Do you like games like space engineers where you get to build machines and fight with them? Then this is your game
Do you like to drive boats and fly planes? Then this is your game.
Do you like RTS games? Then this is your game.

But seriously. This game will eat your life.
You can build anything from submarines to spaceships. I even built an ICBM launching seacrawler with LASERCANNONS!!!

Now to the actual review.
Once you jump in the game you will immediately notice what is going on behind the menu. Those are actual ships from the game, fighting each other. At first you are locked from the campaing and only get to play around with the vehicle designer and story missions, which is not a bad thing. You will be spending most of your time in the designer anyway. Designer is more like a creative mode where you get to spend as much resources as you want and it is a good way to design ships with no fear of enemy attacking you, unless you want them to. Story missions however are small scenarios. There are a few story missions which unlock some blocks for you, so you want to do those as soon as possible. But BEWARE. Story missions are NOT easy.

In the campaing mode you gather resources, build your armada, fight the enemy and do some politics. Not much politics. Mostly bribing. But it plays like an RTS game. You select your units and move them in the map. You build radar arrays to remove the fog of war. You build fortresses which gather resources and build you more ships. You can even automate shipbuilding to some extent. I've played the campaing for 12 hours now, and I only hold 1/4 of the map, with the most dangerous enemies yet to come. So campaing will take time.

If you've read this far I have to warn you. The game has a very steep learning curve. It does have ingame tutorials, but they do not cover everything. Best advice: Read the descriptions on the blocks.

And lastly the positives and the negatives:
+ Freedom
+ It is in alpha and works better than many released titles the days
+ It doesn't really lag, it just goes into slow motion
+ Helpful community
+ Fully configurable AI controlled drones, weapons, ships and pretty much everything ( if your AI controlled plane decides to ram a mountain mid-battle, it's your fault not your planes.)
+ All factions and their lore are community made. The dev chooses which ships to take from community made ships.
+ A nearly perfect mix of building, fighting and RTS
+ It has multiplayer
+ Very steep learning curve (Keeps you interested, but also
+ GIGANTIC SPACE LASER STATION WITH INTERCONTINENTAL BALLISTIC MISSILES AND A FRICKING HUGE CANNON WITH EXPLOSIVE ROUNDS AND SUPERFAST FIRERATE THAT HAS SHIELDS AND A CRAB ON THE TOP...

Negatives:
- Very steep learning curve (it's also a positive, but might scare newcomers)
- Some content is locked behind story missions
- AI needs better tutorials ( Again this is alpha)


Conclusion:
If you want a good allround game with building, fighting and strategy then buy this game. It is alpha but you don't really notice it ingame. If you get stuck and don't know what to do, go to the forums and ask. The community is really helpful and might even download your vehicle blueprint, fix it and send it back to you, all while telling what exactly you did wrong.

10/10 Would let the AI ram my plane to the side of a mountain while chatting with a friend.

Pros:

*difficult to just pick up and go, if you buy this consider checking comunity guides or video`s
*some textures in game are ugly (however being a alpha when this was written it may of changed)
*since story and campaine enermy are literaly aimbots, you feel realy rushed and at times have to go for a meta or cheep tactics to even win a fight.

Surgested improvments :
*some retextures on some items,
*ai is far too accurate at times,  need to be a balence where a player can still be able to at least hit a target without being sniped miles away by something that looks like a pixel on thier screen.

overal: its a fun yet complicated game that is still in alpha and needs a few tweeks, dispite its flaws i can see myself playing hours more of this game, and would recomend other to purchase as well as long as they are look up soem guids and how to" vids before hand."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very Brief Summary:
Obligatory Minecraft reference - using blocks to build ships, planes, spacecraft, floating fortresses and really really really stupidly big guns that may or may not look rather phallic.

Important Points:
* The install size is very small, and the game is very stable and smooth. Loading times are minimal.
* Your constructions will not wobble! Even as they're being shot to pieces, flying through the air or diving across the rolling waves, your creation will not wiggle and the parts will not look like the glue hasn't dried. Once you stick it together, it behaves like a proper, solid object.
* The physics are robust. Whether you're ramming another warship, or just trying to make one that doesn't sink the moment you put it in the water, you can rely on the physics to make sense.
* The combat is fantastic, whether you're manually aiming a weapon or leaving it up to AI modules that don't actually suck. Imagine Homeworld's colourful, trail-filled battles with Eve's general ship control, but with the added bonus of being able to walk around your ship and man the guns yourself.
* You will spend too much time in this game, and neglect your wife/job/personal hygeine.

Important features:
* Comes with a huge list of pre-built vehicles, from tiny submarines to flying fortresses.
* Weapons systems that can be customised in painstaking detail - if you want, you can build a cannon that runs the entire length of your ship, or an automated missile turret with 20 laser-guided missiles.
* Single missions that act like challenges, which can be played with default vehicles or your own creations.
* A campaign mode that's like one big RTS game, where all the units and structures can be designed by you.
* The game is full of tooltips, documentation, visual examples and prefabricated components.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is by far one of the most enjoyable games I have played in a very long time. It gives me the same feeling Minecraft did on that first day. It's packed with content and endless possibilities.

Functionality:

One of the most powerful aspects of this game is the building system. The game offers two styles for building. One is much like Minecraft, and the other is unlike any game before. You are able to quickly and easily switch between the two by hitting F3. Where one building style lacks speed, the other picks up. Building vast expanses of wood for a ship? Try using the Keyboard mode. Trying to piece together the perfect engine? Use the mouse mode to be more accurate and percise while having full rotational control and snappy movement.

Features:

All that I have played at the moment is the Co-op campaign with my friend. We are about 15 hours in, and have built several things. The game is packed with tons of menus and features that can be somewhat overwhealming at first. As time goes, you begin to understand every menu and feature and at some point, about 10 hours in, it all clicks. Building becomes quick and easy, the battle events bring pure elation and excitement, and the laid back time between battles allows for you to truly create and expand. The game offers features for both visually focused players, and those who prefer stratergy. With an expansive and massive map, you will easily be able to put hundreds of hours into the game and still create new and exciting builds and fleets.

Mechanics:

One of the most driving aspects of the game is the adaptability of the physics. You can build almost any creation you wish. From submarine, to ocean liner, flying bases, planes, helicopters, airships, rockets, spacecraft, space stations... It's virtually endless. Even land vehicles are a thing. The physics allow for realistic events, like buoyancy, lift, drag, wind, gravity, and anything else which brings the world together. Building a boat takes a little planning as you must keep it from becoming too top heavy and flipping over. As well, the game tends to automatically create things like windows and various other structures based on block configuration, allowing for beautiful and dynamic builds without extreme effort.

Visuals:

On the surface, the visuals are simply acceptable. As you become more involved in the game, however, they start to make sense. The islands and ships you encounter, as well as those you build will become ever more beautiful. To account for issues during battle, the game will automatically slow and present awesome 'slow-mo' events to prevent your CPU from exploding. A very clever way of handling massive ship battles and constant explosions. The art style is something like Borderlands, which actually makes the game even better. Landmasses and the world looks more realistic, with your character and ships looking more Borderlandish. This makes the game feel happy, even with the dogs of war howling in the distance.

Audio:

Possibly the weakest point of the game. It has sub-par audio. Engine and ocean noises are there, but fairly generic. Music during battles is great, and interestingly, there is hardly ever music during peacetime. This doesn't seem to bother anyone though, as it presents a more calm tone and allows the user to focus on building. None of the noises are annoying, even after playing for 6 hours straight. The game audio is acceptable, but should be improved as development extends, which I believe will happen.

Conclusion:

Do you like building, learning, exploring, growing and being a pirate? Are you an engineer? Do you enjoy Minecraft but want something with a more interactive environment? This game is for you. It offers much more than just Co-op multiplayer as well. There are PVP teams, deathmatches, missions, singleplayer, design (creative) mode and several other game types. If you are looking for something revolutionary and are willing to put a few hours into learning the game, you will not be dissapointed. Whether you want to load your ships with AI and watch them rain hell, or control the weapons yourself and unleash terror upon your enemies, this game is astounding.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This and KSP are the best early acess titles i ever played. this game is the regular block building game everyone and their dogs are making, but oh wait! this one has the following features:
Complex building: you have to build engines in a certain way to make them powerfull and efficient, you can fully customize your weapon systems, and each thing you make is challenging. expect to spend hours building ships. even a small ship can take 1 hour+, because you have to setup the AI, pimp the ship, airship, plane, or spaceship, to make sure it will work.
Why does it need to work? because of the Campaing!
thats right, this game has a challenging campaing, wich is played in a rts style way. it has fog of war, so you need to build radars to see the enemy. you can order your units to go to a certain place, and the world is freaking HUGE. expect to spend several hours to finish the campaing. and its great to launch the behemoth that took you 12 hours to build into the campaign, and see it absolutely destroying the enemy! Theres also a campaing editor, where you can make your own world and customize the factions! so it has endless replayability!
Overall, this is one of the most fleshed out EA titles on steam, far from dogshit like starforge. buy it. BUY IT NOW!

Tbh its a pretty fun game, but it can be confusing at times.


Overall i give it a 9/10. The physics engine is great, but it can be a bit... Weird.... at times. Like i said, building can be confusing at times. But what I don't like is that you have to unlock certain parts by doing campaign missions. But that isn't exactly a bad thing. It allows you to expand your creativity by making a working ship! Its a great game to play with friends, and blow up ships by planting ammo barrels on the deck of the ship.


Or make the entire ship out of ammo barrels.


That works too.



Im not lying. I got with some friends and we put ammo barrels on the deck of a ship. And then we blew it up with missiles. It was fun.

Also this game isn't for casual players who want to just clap their hands and a ship suddenly appears. You need to put effort and time into your ship if you want it to be good. Or you could just always load a pre-built ship....

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From The Depths. Status of review = Early Access.

Graphics 8.5/10.
For the game and what I believe it is supposed to be ( Building/RTS ) Things at this moment are Really well done, Everything looks fairly clean, including the water and land textures. as well as the majority of Block textures.

Gameplay 8/10.
I actually want to give this one a 10/10, But a few things hold me back. The majority of ship/fortress and or constructable control is what it needs to be. Resource gathering I find is grand for this game as you just need ot provide enough power and construct the appropriate collector to get what you need ( Over time that is ).

But the shining gem that is still left in the dirt is the AI control and it's rather stunted options as to what you can do, a fair amount of ships that I have made or came across in the workshop do horribly dissapointing things. Flying/propelling directly into other constructables, Nose diving into terrain or water, or all together just blind running suicide missions into enemy ships.

Overall 8/10.
For it's place in Early Access it is quite well done and has a lot of potential to evolve into a really beautiful game.

Worth it at full Price?
Well unless you are a supporter of Early Access and know what that really means, or have a passion for a game of this type then I personally recommend waiting to grab this the next time it is on a Steam Sale.

This is a really great game. A little hidden though dunno why because i was really bored before i discovered this game (when I looked at the picture i thought it was just another dumb battleship game but its not!!) and I am so glad I found it. In a sense this game is a mixture of space engineers and robocraft except you build your own weapons. You can build anything from subs to spacecraft.

it is really stable for being in early access and I haven't had any game breaking bugs at all.

The weapon creation system is great you can create from a simple machine gun to a massive super cannon. You can build awesome missiles and torpedos and even build lasers!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Picked this game up and have refunded it but i may pick it up if they fix up optimization as it always seems to lag even with a gtx 970. Also i think this game NEEDS an in depth tutorial as i found the building very confusing and barely anything was explained. I refunded the game and i kinda regret it due to the fact they most likely will fix what needs to be fixed and add an in depth tutorial in the future. I will be keeping an eye on it for sure and maybe pick it up later on.

Final Verdict: Even tho i did refund the game i will most likely pick it up if things improve. It is very interesting concept for a game that has been executed very well however it is very confusing when you first pick it up. So i will recomend this game for people who like complex games and i would advise people who have little patience ( like me ) to wait till a helpful tutorial is added.
